[[Proton-proton chain reaction|Proton-Proton]] (PP), [[CNO cycle|CNO]] and [[Triple-alpha process|Triple-α]] fusion processes at different temperatures:
''The dashed line shows the combined energy generation of the PP and CNO processes within a star. At the Sun's core temperature, the PP process is more efficient.'']] {{See also|Stellar nucleosynthesis}} All main-sequence stars have a core region where energy is generated by nuclear fusion. The temperature and density of this core are at the levels necessary to sustain the energy production that will support the remainder of the star. A reduction of energy production would cause the overlaying mass to compress the core, resulting in an increase in the fusion rate because of higher temperature and pressure. Likewise an increase in energy production would cause the star to expand, lowering the pressure at the core. Thus the star forms a self-regulating system in [[hydrostatic equilibrium]] that is stable over the course of its main sequence lifetime. Main-sequence stars employ two types of hydrogen fusion processes, and the rate of energy generation from each type depends on the temperature in the core region. Astronomers divide the main sequence into upper and lower parts, based on which of the two is the dominant fusion process. In the lower main sequence, energy is primarily generated as the result of the [[proton-proton chain]], which directly fuses hydrogen together in a series of stages to produce helium. Stars in the upper main sequence have sufficiently high core temperatures to efficiently use the [[CNO cycle]]. (See the chart.) This process uses atoms of [[carbon]], [[nitrogen]] and [[oxygen]] as intermediaries in the process of fusing hydrogen into helium. At a stellar core temperature of 18 million [[Kelvin]], the PP process and CNO cycle are equally efficient, and each type generates half of the star's net luminosity. As this is the core temperature of a star with about 1.5 {{solar mass}}, the upper main sequence consists of stars above this mass. Thus, roughly speaking, stars of spectral class F or cooler belong to the lower main sequence, while A-type stars or hotter are upper main-sequence stars. The transition in primary energy production from one form to the other spans a range difference of less than a single solar mass. In the Sun, a one solar-mass star, only 1.5% of the energy is generated by the CNO cycle. By contrast, stars with 1.8 {{solar mass}} or above generate almost their entire energy output through the CNO cycle. The observed upper limit for a main-sequence star is 120–200 {{solar mass}}. The theoretical explanation for this limit is that stars above this mass can not radiate energy fast enough to remain stable, so any additional mass will be ejected in a series of pulsations until the star reaches a stable limit. The lower limit for sustained proton–proton nuclear fusion is about 0.08 {{solar mass}} or 80 times the mass of [[Jupiter]]. Below this threshold are sub-stellar objects that can not sustain hydrogen fusion, known as [[brown dwarf]]s. == Structure == {{Main|Stellar structure}} [[File:Solar internal structure.svg|right|upright=1.0|thumb|This diagram shows a cross-section of a Sun-like star, showing the internal structure.]] Because there is a temperature difference between the core and the surface, or [[photosphere]], energy is transported outward. The two modes for transporting this energy are [[radiation]] and [[convection]]. A [[radiation zone]], where energy is transported by radiation, is stable against convection and there is very little mixing of the plasma. By contrast, in a [[convection zone]] the energy is transported by bulk movement of plasma, with hotter material rising and cooler material descending. Convection is a more efficient mode for carrying energy than radiation, but it will only occur under conditions that create a steep temperature gradient. In massive stars (above 10 {{solar mass}}) the rate of energy generation by the CNO cycle is very sensitive to temperature, so the fusion is highly concentrated at the core. Consequently, there is a high temperature gradient in the core region, which results in a convection zone for more efficient energy transport. This mixing of material around the core removes the helium ash from the hydrogen-burning region, allowing more of the hydrogen in the star to be consumed during the main-sequence lifetime. The outer regions of a massive star transport energy by radiation, with little or no convection. Intermediate-mass stars such as [[Sirius]] may transport energy primarily by radiation, with a small core convection region. Medium-sized, low-mass stars like the Sun have a core region that is stable against convection, with a convection zone near the surface that mixes the outer layers. This results in a steady buildup of a helium-rich core, surrounded by a hydrogen-rich outer region. By contrast, cool, very low-mass stars (below 0.4 {{solar mass}}) are convective throughout. Thus the helium produced at the core is distributed across the star, producing a relatively uniform atmosphere and a proportionately longer main sequence lifespan. == Luminosity-color variation == [[File:Sun920607.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|The [[Sun]] is the most familiar example of a main-sequence star]] As non-fusing helium ash accumulates in the core of a main-sequence star, the reduction in the abundance of hydrogen per unit mass results in a gradual lowering of the fusion rate within that mass. Since it is the outflow of fusion-supplied energy that supports the higher layers of the star, the core is compressed, producing higher temperatures and pressures. Both factors increase the rate of fusion thus moving the equilibrium towards a smaller, denser, hotter core producing more energy whose increased outflow pushes the higher layers further out. Thus there is a steady increase in the luminosity and radius of the star over time. For example, the luminosity of the early Sun was only about 70% of its current value. As a star ages this luminosity increase changes its position on the HR diagram. This effect results in a broadening of the main sequence band because stars are observed at random stages in their lifetime. That is, the main sequence band develops a thickness on the HR diagram; it is not simply a narrow line. Other factors that broaden the main sequence band on the HR diagram include uncertainty in the distance to stars and the presence of unresolved [[binary star]]s that can alter the observed stellar parameters. However, even perfect observation would show a fuzzy main sequence because mass is not the only parameter that affects a star's color and luminosity. Variations in chemical composition caused by the initial abundances, the star's [[Stellar evolution|evolutionary status]], interaction with a [[Binary star|close companion]], [[Stellar rotation|rapid rotation]], or a [[Stellar magnetic field|magnetic field]] can all slightly change a main-sequence star's HR diagram position, to name just a few factors. As an example, there are [[Metallicity|metal-poor stars]] (with a very low abundance of elements with higher atomic numbers than helium) that lie just below the main sequence and are known as [[subdwarf]]s. These stars are fusing hydrogen in their cores and so they mark the lower edge of main sequence fuzziness caused by variance in chemical composition. A nearly vertical region of the HR diagram, known as the [[instability strip]], is occupied by pulsating [[variable star]]s known as [[Cepheid variable]]s. These stars vary in magnitude at regular intervals, giving them a pulsating appearance. The strip intersects the upper part of the main sequence in the region of class ''A'' and ''F'' stars, which are between one and two solar masses. Pulsating stars in this part of the instability strip that intersects the upper part of the main sequence are called [[Delta Scuti variable]]s. Main-sequence stars in this region experience only small changes in magnitude and so this variation is difficult to detect. Other classes of unstable main-sequence stars, like [[Beta Cephei variable]]s, are unrelated to this instability strip. == Lifetime == [[File:Isochrone ZAMS Z2pct.png|upright=1.0|right|thumb|This plot gives an example of the mass-luminosity relationship for zero-age main-sequence stars. The mass and luminosity are relative to the present-day Sun.]] The total amount of energy that a star can generate through nuclear fusion of hydrogen is limited by the amount of hydrogen fuel that can be consumed at the core. For a star in equilibrium, the energy generated at the core must be at least equal to the energy radiated at the surface. Since the luminosity gives the amount of energy radiated per unit time, the total life span can be estimated, to [[Orders of approximation|first approximation]], as the total energy produced divided by the star's luminosity. For a star with at least 0.5 {{solar mass}}, when the hydrogen supply in its core is exhausted and it expands to become a [[red giant]], it can start to fuse [[helium]] atoms to form [[carbon]]. The energy output of the helium fusion process per unit mass is only about a tenth the energy output of the hydrogen process, and the luminosity of the star increases. This results in a much shorter length of time in this stage compared to the main sequence lifetime. (For example, the Sun is predicted to spend {{nowrap|130 million years}} burning helium, compared to about 12 billion years burning hydrogen.) Thus, about 90% of the observed stars above 0.5 {{solar mass}} will be on the main sequence. On average, main-sequence stars are known to follow an empirical [[Mass–luminosity relation|mass-luminosity relationship]]. The luminosity (''L'') of the star is roughly proportional to the total mass (''M'') as the following [[power law]]: :\begin{smallmatrix}L\ \propto\ M^{3.5}\end{smallmatrix} This relationship applies to main-sequence stars in the range 0.1–50 {{solar mass}}. The amount of fuel available for nuclear fusion is proportional to the mass of the star. Thus, the lifetime of a star on the main sequence can be estimated by comparing it to solar evolutionary models. The [[Sun]] has been a main-sequence star for about 4.5 billion years and it will become a red giant in 6.5 billion years,{{cite journal | last=Sackmann | first=I.-Juliana |author2=Boothroyd, Arnold I. |author3=Kraemer, Kathleen E. | title=Our Sun. III. Present and Future | journal=Astrophysical Journal |date=November 1993 | volume=418 | pages=457–468 | doi=10.1086/173407 | bibcode=1993ApJ...418..457S}} for a total main sequence lifetime of roughly 1010 years. Hence:{{cite book | first=Carl J. | last=Hansen |author2=Kawaler, Steven D. | date=1994 | title=Stellar Interiors: Physical Principles, Structure, and Evolution | page=28 | publisher=Birkhäuser | isbn=978-0-387-94138-7 }} :\begin{smallmatrix} \tau_{\rm MS}\ \approx \ 10^{10} \text{years} \cdot \left[ \frac{M}{M_{\bigodot}} \right] \cdot \left[ \frac{L_{\bigodot}}{L} \right]\ =\ 10^{10} \text{years} \cdot \left[ \frac{M}{M_{\bigodot}} \right]^{-2.5} \end{smallmatrix} where ''M'' and ''L'' are the mass and luminosity of the star, respectively, \begin{smallmatrix}M_{\bigodot}\end{smallmatrix} is a [[solar mass]], \begin{smallmatrix}L_{\bigodot}\end{smallmatrix} is the [[solar luminosity]] and \tau_{\rm MS} is the star's estimated main sequence lifetime. Although more massive stars have more fuel to burn and might intuitively be expected to last longer, they also radiate a proportionately greater amount with increased mass. This is required by the stellar equation of state; for a massive star to maintain equilibrium, the outward pressure of radiated energy generated in the core not only must but ''will'' rise to match the titanic inward gravitational pressure of its envelope. Thus, the most massive stars may remain on the main sequence for only a few million years, while stars with less than a tenth of a solar mass may last for over a trillion years.{{cite journal | last=Laughlin | first=Gregory |author2=Bodenheimer, Peter |author3=Adams, Fred C. | title=The End of the Main Sequence | journal=The Astrophysical Journal | date=1997 | volume=482 | issue=1 | pages=420–432 | doi= 10.1086/304125 | bibcode=1997ApJ...482..420L}} The exact mass-luminosity relationship depends on how efficiently energy can be transported from the core to the surface. A higher [[Opacity (optics)|opacity]] has an insulating effect that retains more energy at the core, so the star does not need to produce as much energy to remain in [[hydrostatic equilibrium]]. By contrast, a lower opacity means energy escapes more rapidly and the star must burn more fuel to remain in equilibrium.{{cite web | last=Imamura | first=James N. | date=7 February 1995 | url=http://zebu.uoregon.edu/~imamura/208/feb6/mass.html | title=Mass-Luminosity Relationship | publisher=University of Oregon | accessdate=2007-01-08 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061214065335/http://zebu.uoregon.edu/~imamura/208/feb6/mass.html| archivedate = 14 December 2006}} Note, however, that a sufficiently high opacity can result in energy transport via [[convection]], which changes the conditions needed to remain in equilibrium. In high-mass main-sequence stars, the opacity is dominated by [[electron scattering]], which is nearly constant with increasing temperature. Thus the luminosity only increases as the cube of the star's mass. For stars below 10 {{solar mass}}, the opacity becomes dependent on temperature, resulting in the luminosity varying approximately as the fourth power of the star's mass.{{cite book | first=Claus E. | last=Rolfs |author2=Rodney, William S. | date=1988 | title=Cauldrons in the Cosmos: Nuclear Astrophysics | publisher=University of Chicago Press | isbn=978-0-226-72457-7 }} For very low-mass stars, molecules in the atmosphere also contribute to the opacity. Below about 0.5 {{solar mass}}, the luminosity of the star varies as the mass to the power of 2.3, producing a flattening of the slope on a graph of mass versus luminosity. Even these refinements are only an approximation, however, and the mass-luminosity relation can vary depending on a star's composition.{{cite journal | last=Kroupa | first=Pavel | title=The Initial Mass Function of Stars: Evidence for Uniformity in Variable Systems | journal=Science | date=2002 | volume=295 | issue=5552 | pages=82–91 | url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/295/5552/82 | accessdate=2007-12-03 | doi=10.1126/science.1067524 | pmid=11778039 |arxiv = astro-ph/0201098 |bibcode = 2002Sci...295...82K }} == Evolutionary tracks == {{Main|Stellar evolution}} [[File:Evolutionary track 1m.svg|thumb|left|Evolutionary track of a star like the sun]] When a main-sequence star has consumed the hydrogen at its core, the loss of energy generation causes its gravitational collapse to resume and the star evolves off the main sequence. The path which the star follows across the HR diagram is called an evolutionary track.{{cite book|author=Icko Iben|title=Stellar Evolution Physics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IU357EiecWwC&pg=PA1481|date=29 November 2012|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-107-01657-6|pages=1481–}} Stars with less than {{solar mass|0.23}},{{cite journal |author1=Adams, Fred C. |author2=Laughlin, Gregory | title=A Dying Universe: The Long Term Fate and Evolution of Astrophysical Objects | journal=Reviews of Modern Physics |date=April 1997 | volume=69 | issue=2 | pages=337–372 | doi=10.1103/RevModPhys.69.337 | bibcode=1997RvMP...69..337A|arxiv = astro-ph/9701131 }} are predicted to directly become [[white dwarf]]s when energy generation by nuclear fusion of hydrogen at their core comes to a halt although no stars are old enough for this to have occurred. [[File:Open cluster HR diagram ages.gif|right|thumb|upright=1.2|[[H-R Diagram]] for two open clusters: [[NGC 188]] (blue) is older and shows a lower turn off from the main sequence than [[Messier 67|M67]] (yellow). The dots outside the two sequences are mostly foreground and background stars with no relation to the clusters.]] In stars more massive than {{solar mass|0.23}}, the hydrogen surrounding the helium core reaches sufficient temperature and pressure to undergo fusion, forming a hydrogen-burning shell and causing the outer layers of the star to expand and cool. The stage as these stars move away from the main sequence is known as the [[subgiant branch]]; it is relatively brief and appears as a [[Hertzsprung gap|gap]] in the evolutionary track since few stars are observed at that point. When the helium core of low-mass stars becomes degenerate, or the outer layers of intermediate-mass stars cool sufficiently to become opaque, their hydrogen shells increase in temperature and the stars start to become more luminous. This is known as the [[red giant branch]]; it is a relatively long-lived stage and it appears prominently in H-R diagrams. These stars will eventually end their lives as white dwarfs.{{cite web | author=Staff | date=12 October 2006 | url=http://outreach.atnf.csiro.au/education/senior/astrophysics/stellarevolution_postmain.html | title=Post-Main Sequence Stars | publisher=Australia Telescope Outreach and Education | accessdate=2008-01-08 }}{{cite journal |author1=Girardi, L. |author2=Bressan, A. |author3=Bertelli, G. |author4=Chiosi, C. | title=Evolutionary tracks and isochrones for low- and intermediate-mass stars: From 0.15 to 7 Msun, and from Z=0.0004 to 0.03 | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics Supplement | date=2000 | volume=141 | issue=3 | pages=371–383 | doi=10.1051/aas:2000126|arxiv = astro-ph/9910164 |bibcode = 2000A&AS..141..371G }} The most massive stars do not become red giants, instead their cores quickly become hot enough to fuse helium and eventually heavier elements and they are known as [[supergiant]]s. They follow approximately horizontal evolutionary tracks from the main sequence across the top of the H-R diagram. Supergiants are relatively rare and do not show prominently on most H-R diagrams. Their cores will eventually collapse, usually leading to a supernova and leaving behind either a [[neutron star]] or [[black hole]].{{cite web|last=Sitko |first=Michael L. |date=24 March 2000 |url=http://www.physics.uc.edu/~sitko/Spring00/4-Starevol/starevol.html |title=Stellar Structure and Evolution |publisher=University of Cincinnati |accessdate=2007-12-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050326090756/http://www.physics.uc.edu/~sitko/Spring00/4-Starevol/starevol.html |archivedate=26 March 2005 }} When a [[star cluster|cluster of stars]] is formed at about the same time, the main sequence lifespan of these stars will depend on their individual masses. The most massive stars will leave the main sequence first, followed in sequence by stars of ever lower masses. The position where stars in the cluster are leaving the main sequence is known as the [[turnoff point]]. By knowing the main sequence lifespan of stars at this point, it becomes possible to estimate the age of the cluster.{{cite journal | last=Krauss | first=Lawrence M. |author2=Chaboyer, Brian | title=Age Estimates of Globular Clusters in the Milky Way: Constraints on Cosmology | journal=Science | date=2003 | volume=299 | issue=5603 | pages=65–69 | doi= 10.1126/science.1075631 | pmid=12511641 |bibcode = 2003Sci...299...65K }} == Notes == {{Portal|Star|Astronomy}} {{reflist|group=note}} == References == {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web | url=http://cass.ucsd.edu/public/tutorial/HR.html | title=The Hertzsprung-Russell Diagram | author=Harding E. The vertical [[Joint (geology)|joint]]s create sheer cliff faces. | unitof = [[Hamilton Group]] | subunits = [[#Named members|See: Named members]] | underlies = [[Mahantango Formation]] and [[Millboro Shale]] | overlies = [[Huntersville Chert]], [[Needmore Shale]], and [[Onondaga Formation]] | thickness = up to {{convert|900|ft|m|-1}} | extent = {{convert|600|mi|km}}{{cite web |url=http://www.aapg.org/explorer/2008/03mar/marcellus.cfm |title=Appalachian Basin's Marcellus – the new target : Another Shale Making Seismic Waves | date=March 2008| first = Louise S.| last = Durham |accessdate=2008-04-06 |work=AAPG Explorer|publisher = American Association of Petroleum Geologists}} }} The '''Marcellus Formation''' (also classified as the '''Marcellus Subgroup''' of the [[Hamilton Group]], '''Marcellus Member''' of the Romney Formation, or simply the '''Marcellus Shale''') is a [[Middle Devonian]] age [[Geological unit|unit]] of [[sedimentary rock]] found in eastern [[North America]]. Named for a distinctive [[outcrop]] near the village of [[Marcellus (village), New York|Marcellus]], [[New York (state)|New York]], in the [[United States]], it extends throughout much of the [[Appalachian Basin]].Ryder, R.T., Swezey, C.S., Crangle, R.D., Jr., and Trippi, M.T., 2008, Geologic cross section E-E’ through the central Appalachian Basin from the Findlay Arch, Wood County, Ohio, to the Valley and Ridge Province, Pendleton County, West Virginia: U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Map SIM-2985, 2 sheets with 48-page pamphlet. https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/sim2985Ryder, R.T., Crangle, R.D., Jr., Trippi, M.H., Swezey, C.S., Lentz, E.E., Rowan, E.L., and Hope, R.S., 2009, Geologic cross section D-D’ through the central Appalachian basin from the Findlay arch, Sandusky County, Ohio, to the Valley and Ridge province, Hardy County, West Virginia: U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Map SIM-3067, 2 sheets with 52-page pamphlet. https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/sim3067 Ryder, R.T., Trippi, M.H., Swezey, C.S., Crangle, R.D., Jr., Hope, R.S., Rowan, E.L., and Lentz, E.E., 2012, Geologic cross section C-C’ through the central Appalachian basin from near the Findlay Arch, north-central Ohio, to the Valley and Ridge Province, Bedford County, south-central Pennsylvania: U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Map SIM-3172, 2 sheets with 70-page pamphlet. https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/sim3172 The unit name usage by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) includes ''Marcellus Shale'' and ''Marcellus Formation''.See unit names marked by an asterisk at [https://ngmdb.usgs.gov/Geolex/Units/Marcellus_2635.html Geolex] The unit was first described and named as the "Marcellus shales" by J. Hall in 1839.New York Geological Survey, 3rd Report, p. 295-296 [[Stratigraphy|Stratigraphically]], the Marcellus is the lowest unit of the [[Devonian]] age Hamilton Group, and is divided into several sub-units. Although black [[shale]] is the dominant [[lithology]], it also contains lighter shales and [[interbedded]] [[limestone]] layers due to sea level variation during its [[Sedimentary depositional environment|deposition]] almost {{Ma|400 }}.{{cite web |url=http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/topogeo/tbr/tbrintro.aspx | title = Trenton and Black River Carbonates in the Union Furnace Area of Blair and Huntingdon Counties, Pennsylvania : Introduction| date= 2004-05-26|work=Field Trip Guidebook for the Eastern Section AAPG Annual Meeting, September 10, 2003 and the PAPG Spring Field Trip, May 26, 2004 |accessdate=2008-06-14| author= Harper, John A.|author2=Christopher D. Laughrey |author3=Jaime Kostelnik |author4=David P. Gold |author5=Arnold G. Doden |publisher=Pennsylvania Geological Survey}} The black shale was deposited in relatively deep water devoid of [[oxygen]], and is only sparsely [[fossiliferous]]. Most fossils are contained in the limestone members, and the fossil record in these layers provides important [[paleontology|paleontological]] insights on [[faunal stage|faunal turnovers]]. The shale contains largely untapped [[natural gas]] reserves, and its proximity to the high-demand markets along the [[East Coast of the United States]] makes it an attractive target for [[energy development]] and [[export]].{{cite web | url = http://www.petroleumnews.com/pntruncate/246893563.shtml | title = Appalachia to the rescue: Could Devonian shales deep under the Appalachians supply trillions of cubic feet of much needed natural gas for the U.S.? | author = Alan Bailey | publisher = Petroleum News |accessdate = 2008-04-05}} The black shales also contain [[iron ore]] that was used in the early economic development of the region, and [[uranium]] and [[pyrite]] which are environmental hazards. The [[Fissility (geology)|fissile]] shales are also easily [[erosion|eroded]], presenting additional [[civil engineering|civil]] and [[environmental engineering]] challenges. ==Geology== ===Description=== The Marcellus Formation is a [[black shale]] that may contain [[limestone]] [[Bed (geology)|beds]] and concentrations of iron [[pyrite]] ([[Iron|Fe]][[Sulfur|S]]2) and [[siderite]] (Fe[[carbonate|CO3]]).{{cite web |url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/docrec/pdoc1724.pdf |title=HRS Documentation Record, Safety Light Corporation, EPA ID No. PAD987295276 |accessdate=2008-04-02 |format= PDF|work=Hazard Ranking System|publisher=[[United States Environmental Protection Agency]]}} Its sedimentary structure, or bedding, is moderately well developed. Like most shales, it tends to split easily along the bedding plane, a property known as [[fissility (geology)|fissility]]. Lighter colored shales in the upper portion of the formation tend to split into small thin-edged fragments after exposure.{{cite book | author = MacFarlane, James R. | year = 1890 |origyear=1878 | title =An American Geological Railway Guide : Giving the Geological Formation at Every Railway Station,... | edition = 2nd | pages = 30–31, 33 | publisher = D. Appleton | location = New York | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=AV8PAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA30 | lccn = tmp96004299 }} These fragments may have [[rust]] stains from exposure of pyrite to air, and tiny [[gypsum]] ([[calcium|Ca]][[sulfate|SO4]]·2[[Hydrate|H2O]]) crystals from the reaction between pyrite and limestone particles. Fresh exposures of the pyriteiferous shale may develop the secondary [[Mineralization (geology)|mineralization]] of orange [[limonite]] (Fe[[Oxygen|O]]([[hydroxide|OH]])·nH2O), and the pale yellow [[efflorescence]] or bloom of [[sulfur]], associated with [[acid rock drainage]].{{cite web |url=http://www.wvgs.wvnet.edu/www/statemap/statemap06.htm |title= Milam and Cow Knob Quadrangles | author = McDowell, Ronald ; Katharine Lee Avary, Eric Lewis, James Britton, Paula Hunt|author2=Paula Waggy |author3=Megan Ganak | year = 2006| publisher =West Virginia Geological & Economic Survey |work= WVGES STATEMAP Projects |accessdate=2008-07-13}} [[File:MarcellusShaleCloseUp.jpg|alt=Many irregular pieces of rock in different sizes.|thumb|left|Fragments below exposure of [[Fissility (geology)|fissile]] Marcellus black shale at [[Marcellus (village), New York|Marcellus, N.Y.]]]] Pyrite is especially abundant near the base, and the upper contacts of limestones, but [[framboid]]al microcrystals and [[euhedral]] crystals of pyrite occur throughout the organic-rich deposits. The Marcellus also contains [[uranium]],{{cite journal | author = Hand, B.M. |author2=Banikowski, J.E. | year = 1988 | title = Radon in Onondaga County, New York; paleohydrogeology and redistribution of uranium in Paleozoic sedimentary rocks | journal = Geology | volume = 16 | issue = 9 | pages = 775–778 | url = http://geology.geoscienceworld.org/cgi/content/abstract/16/9/775 | accessdate = 2008-05-03 | doi = 10.1130/0091-7613(1988)016<0775:RIOCNY>2.3.CO;2 |bibcode = 1988Geo....16..775H }}{{cite journal | author1 = Harrell, J.A. | author2 = Belsito, M.E. | author3 = Kumar, A. | year = 1991 | title = Radon hazards associated with outcrops of Ohio Shale in Ohio | journal = Environmental Geology | volume = 18 | issue = 1 | pages = 17–26 | url = http://www.springerlink.com/index/U60V51862RJ08843.pdf |format=PDF| doi = 10.1007/BF01704574 | accessdate = 2008-05-03 |bibcode = 1991EnGeo..18...17H }} and the [[radioactive decay]] of the [[uranium-238]] (238U) makes it a [[source rock]] for radioactive [[radon]] gas (222Rn).{{cite book |author=Wanty, Richard B. |title=Field studies of radon in rocks, soils, and water |publisher=C.K. Smoley |location=Chelsea, Michigan |year=1993 |page=216 |isbn=0-87371-955-7 }} Measured total organic content of the Marcellus Formation ranges from less than 1% in eastern New York, to over 11% in the central part of the state, and the shale may contain enough carbon to support [[combustion]].{{cite book | author = Dewees, John H. |author2=Ashburner, Charles A. | year = 1878 | title =Report of Progress in the Juniata District on the Fossil Iron Ore Beds of Middle Pennsylvania | publisher = Board of commissioners for the Second geological survey | location = Harrisburg | lccn = gs07000714 }} The more organic-rich black shales can be [[Bitumen|bituminous]], but are too old to contain [[bituminous coal]] formed from land plants. In [[petroleum geology]], these black shales are an important [[source rock]] that filled conventional [[petroleum reservoir]]s in overlying formations, are an unconventional [[shale gas]] reservoir, and are an [[Permeability (earth sciences)|impermeable]] seal that traps underlying conventional [[natural gas]] reservoirs.{{cite journal |url=http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/info/carbon/documents/geological_assessment_rev_091806.pdf |format= PDF | title = Assessment of Geological Sequestration Potential in Pennsylvania | publisher = Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources | date = 2006-09-18 | accessdate = 2008-07-07}} To the west the formation may produce liquid [[petroleum]]; further north heating during deeper burial more than 240 million years ago [[Cracking (chemistry)|cracked]] this oil into gas.{{cite journal | author1 = Laughrey, C.D. | author2 = Billman, D.A. | author3 = Canich, M.R. | year = 2004 | title = Petroleum geology and geochemistry of the Council Run gas field, north central Pennsylvania | journal = AAPG Bulletin | volume = 88 | issue = 2 | pages = 213–239 | doi = 10.1306/10060301104 }} ===Extent=== The Marcellus is found throughout the [[Allegheny Plateau]] region of the northern [[Appalachian Basin]] of North America. In the United States, the Marcellus shale runs across the [[Southern Tier]] and [[Finger Lakes]] regions of [[New York (state)|New York]], in northern and western [[Pennsylvania]], eastern [[Ohio]], through western [[Maryland]], and throughout most of [[West Virginia]] extending across the state line into extreme western [[Virginia]].{{cite web|url=http://live.psu.edu/story/28116 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081222111707/http://live.psu.edu/story/28116 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-12-22 |title=Unconventional natural gas reservoir could boost U.S. supply |date=2008-01-17 |accessdate=2008-04-04 |work=Penn State Live |publisher=[[Pennsylvania State University]] }} The Marcellus bedrock in eastern Pennsylvania{{cite web |url = http://www.fracktrack.org/index.php |title = Pennsylvania Marcellus Shale Mapping Application|accessdate=2011-03-17}} extends across the [[Delaware River]] into extreme western [[New Jersey]]. It also exists in the subsurface of a small portion of [[Kentucky]] and [[Tennessee]].{{cite web |url=http://geology.com/articles/marcellus-shale.shtml |title=Marcellus Shale Gas: New Research Results Surprise Geologists! |work=geology.com |publisher = Dr. Hobart M. King|accessdate=2008-05-03}} Below [[Lake Erie]], it can be found crossing the border into [[Canada]], where it stretches between [[Port Stanley, Ontario|Port Stanley]] and [[Long Point, Ontario|Long Point]] to [[St. Thomas, Ontario|St. Thomas]] in southern [[Ontario]]. [http://stopfrackingontario.wordpress.com/fracking/in-ontario/ Stop Fracking Ontario: Shale in Ontario]{{cite web |url=https://archive.org/details/hydrogeologyofso00snsiuoft |title=The Hydrology of Southern Ontario: Second Edition|accessdate=2008-04-06 |author1=Singer, S.N. |author2=Cheng, C.K. |author3=Scafe, M.G. |year=2003|format=PDF |work=Hydrology of Ontario Series|publisher=Ontario Ministry of the Environment}} ====Outcrops==== [[File:Middle Delaware River above Walpack Bend.jpg|alt=A placid river winds its way through farmland and forest.|thumb|upright|[[Delaware River]] above Walpack Bend, where it leaves the buried valley eroded from Marcellus Shale bedrock]] The Marcellus appears in outcrops along the northern margin of the formation in central New York. There, the two [[Joint (geology)|joint]] planes in the Marcellus are nearly at right angles, each making cracks in the formation that run perpendicular to the bedding plane, which lies almost level. These joints form smooth nearly vertical [[cliff]]s, and the intersecting joint planes form projecting corners in the rock faces. Once exposed, the weathered faces lose most of their organic carbon, turning from black or dark gray to a lighter shade of gray. Outcrops of the Marcellus can contain very small beds that resemble [[coal]]. The New York outcrops, and others further south in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, were extensively excavated in the early 19th century, sometimes at great expense, in the false hope of finding minable [[coal seam]]s.{{cite book | author = Vanuxem, L. | year = 1842 | title = Geology of New York, Pt. 3, Comprising the Survey of the Third Geological District | series = Natural History of New York. | publisher =Carroll and Cook | location = Albany, New York | lccn = gs07000386 }} In [[Perry County, Pennsylvania]] along the [[Juniata River]] the false coal beds become up to {{convert|.3|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} thick, but they did not produce a valuable fuel, despite the considerable effort expended to mine it from the surrounding hills. [[Seaweed]] and marine plants probably formed the false coal. True coal is formed from terrestrial plants, which only began to appear in Marcellus and later fossils.{{cite book | author = MacFarlane, J. | year = 1875 | title = The Coal-regions of America: Their Topography, Geology, and Development. | publisher = D. Appleton and Company | edition = 3rd | page = 612 | lccn = 03026433 }}{{cite book | author = Ripley, G. |author2=Dana, C.A. | year = 1861 | title = The New American Cyclopaedia: A Popular Dictionary of General Knowledge | publisher = D. Appleton and Company | location = New York | lccn = 07019446 }} Close proximity to the surface of Marcellus bedrock south of the New York outcrops makes an east-west band running through the city of [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]] a high-risk area for radon as an [[Indoor air quality|indoor air pollutant]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nyradon.org/abstracts.htm#1a |title=New York State Studies (published) |work=Radon – The State of Radon in New York |publisher=NYS Department of Health Wadsworth Center |accessdate=2008-05-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080808120456/http://www.nyradon.org/abstracts.htm |archivedate=2008-08-08 |df= }} From the surface exposures along the northern and eastern margins, the formation descends to depths of over {{convert|2700|m|ft|-2|abbr=on}} below the surface in southern Pennsylvania. ===Structural geology=== Upturned beds are exposed in sections of the [[Fold (geology)|folded]] [[Ridge-and-Valley Appalachians]], including exposures on the flanks and axis of the Broad Top [[Synclinorium]] in south central Pennsylvania.{{cite web |url=http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/topogeo/openfile/allensville.pdf |title= Bedrock Geologic Map of the Allensville Quadrangle, Huntingdon and Mifflin Counties, Pennsylvania|format= PDF|work= Open File Report OFBM 07-02.0|publisher=Pennsylvania Geological Survey|author1=McElroy, Thomas A. |author2=Hoskins, Donald M. |page=12}} Exposed beds are nearly horizontal on the Allegheny Plateau,{{cite web |url=http://www.geosc.psu.edu/~engelder/marcellus/marcellus.html |title=Outcrops of the Marcellus Formation|author=Engelder, T.|work=|publisher=The Pennsylvania State University|accessdate=2008-05-03}} but upturned to form slightly overturned beds found along the [[Allegheny Front]].{{cite journal |author1=Engelder, T. |author2=Lash, G. |year=2008 |title=Systematic joints in Devonian black shale: A target for horizontal drilling in the Appalachian Basin (draft) |url=http://www.papgrocks.org/engelder%20lash.pdf |accessdate=2008-05-03 |format=PDF |publisher=Pittsburgh Association of Petroleum Geologists |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727163318/http://www.papgrocks.org/engelder%20lash.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-27 |df= }} From [[Wind Gap, Pennsylvania]] heading south, the [[Strike and dip|dip]] of the beds steepens, becoming vertical at [[Bowmanstown, Pennsylvania|Bowmanstown]] on the [[Lehigh River]]. Nearby, in the [[Lehigh Gap]] area of Pennsylvania, the Marcellus is extensively [[Fault (geology)|faulted]],{{cite journal | author = Epstein, J.B. | year = 2006 | title = Geology of the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area, New Jersey-Pennsylvania | journal = Excursions in Geology and History: Field Trips in the Middle Atlantic States | page = 52 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=vQdHRNitfOoC&pg=PA47&dq=Geology+Delaware+Water+Gap+Pennsylvania+Epstein | accessdate = 2008-07-07 | doi = 10.1130/2006.fld008(04) | volume = 8 | publisher = Geological Society of America | isbn = 978-0-8137-0008-3 }} and the beds are steeply overturned, with a reverse [[Strike and dip|dip]] angle of up to 40° south. The Marcellus Shale and the fine-grained shales near the middle of the Mahantango Formation are classified by geologists as [[slope-former]]s.{{cite journal | author = Altamura, R.J. | year = 1999 | title = Geologic Mapping UsingcRadar Imagery in the Ridge and Valley Province | url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/topogeo/pub/pageolmag/pdfs/v30n3_4.pdf |format=PDF| journal = Pennsylvania Geology | publisher = Pennsylvania Bureau of Topographic and Geologic Survey | volume= 30 | page = 9 | accessdate = 2008-07-13 | issue = 3/4 }} Marcellus and Mahantango shale beds dipping at 60° to 75° to the west form the west facing slopes of [[Tonoloway Ridge]] on the west flank of the [[Cacapon Mountain]] [[anticline]] in the [[Eastern Panhandle of West Virginia]].{{cite book | author = Grimsley, G.P. |author2=White, I. C. | year = 1916 | title = Jefferson, Berkley, and Morgan counties | series = County Reports | publisher = West Virginia Geological Survey | location = Morgantown, WV | pages = 123, 167, 210, 326 | lccn = gs17000132 }} On the eastern limb of this anticline, beds of these shales dipping to the east at a shallower angle also form the steep slopes on the east side of [[Warm Springs Ridge]]. [[File:Marcellus Bedrock.svg|thumb|left|Bedrock [[geologic map]] showing Marcellus bedrock in New York and Pennsylvania]] ===Surficial geology=== The Marcellus is easily [[erosion|eroded]], and is also found underlying low areas between some Appalachian ridges, forming linear valleys of moderate relief. These bedrock surfaces are typically covered with [[colluvium]] from erosion of stratigraphically higher and more erosion-resistant strata that form the surrounding higher ground. The soils formed from the Marcellus and the overlying Hamilton shales are deep, free of stones, and well suited for [[agriculture]]. Sampling of soil formed on the Marcellus bedrock showed the dominant [[mineralogy]] consisted of [[quartz]], [[illite]], [[montmorillonite]], [[muscovite]], and [[biotite]], with phases of [[todorokite]] and [[trona]] appearing at depths closer to the bedrock.{{cite web|url=http://www.juniata.edu/faculty/mathur/Fornadel_Marcellus_LAS.pdf |title=Dirty work: Soil formation and isotope fractionation behind Brumbaugh Academic Center |first=Andrew P. |last=Fornadel |author2=Ryan D. Mathur |author3=Susan L. Brantley |format=PDF |work= |publisher=Juniata College Geology Department, and the Center for Environmental Kinetics Analysis, Pennsylvania State University |accessdate=2008-07-13 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Upturned beds of the soft shale also capture streams and rivers with relatively straight segments in strike valleys such as the [[Aquashicola Creek]] and [[McMichael Creek]] at the foot of [[The Poconos]], and the long, straight section of the [[Lost River (Cacapon River)|Lost River]] in West Virginia.{{cite journal | author = Rich, J.L. | year = 1939 | title = A Bird's-Eye Cross Section of the Central Appalachian Mountains and Plateau: Washington to Cincinnati | journal = Geographical Review | volume = 29 | issue = 4 | pages = 561–586 | doi = 10.2307/209829 | publisher = Geographical Review, Vol. 29, No. 4 | jstor=209829 }} Below [[Port Jervis, New York]], the Walpack Ridge deflects the [[Delaware River]] into the Minisink Valley, where it follows the southwest [[Strike and dip|strike]] of the eroded Marcellus beds along the Pennsylvania – New Jersey state line for {{convert|40|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} to the end of the ridge at Walpack Bend in the [[Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area]].{{cite web |url=http://www.njgeology.org/enviroed/newsletter/v2n1.pdf |title= Karst in the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area |author1=White, Ron W. |author2=Monteverde, Donald H. |format= PDF|work= Unearthing New Jersey Vol. 2, No. 1 | date=2006-02-01 |accessdate=2008-06-07|publisher=New Jersey Geological Survey}}{{cite book | author = White, I.C. |author2=Chance, H.M. | year = 1882 | title = The geology of Pike and Monroe counties | series = Second Geol. Surv. of Penna., | location = Harrisburg | volume = Rept. of Progress, G6 | pages = 17, 73–80, 114–115 }} The Minisink is a [[buried valley]] where the Delaware flows in a bed of [[glacier|glacial]] [[till]] that buried the eroded Marcellus bedrock during the [[last glacial period]]. This buried valley continues along the strike of the Marcellus southwest from the bend through [[Stroudsburg, Pennsylvania]], and northeast from Port Jervis toward the [[Hudson River]], along the route of the [[Delaware and Hudson Canal]]. [[File:Eastern North American Paleogeograpy Middle Devonian.png|alt=Map of north-eastern North America showing the Illinois Basin, the Michigan Basin and to the east, the Appalachian Basin.|thumb|right|[[Palaeogeography|Paleogeographic]] reconstruction of the [[Appalachian Basin]] area during deposition of the Marcellus{{cite web |url=http://jan.ucc.nau.edu/rcb7/nam.html |title= Paleogeography and Geologic Evolution of North America|first=Ron | last=Blakey |publisher = Northern Arizona University|work= Global Plate Tectonics and Paleogeography|accessdate=2008-07-04}}]] ===Interpretation of Depositional Environment=== Early in the [[Acadian orogeny]], as the [[Acadian Mountains]] were rising up, the black and gray shales of the Hamilton Group began accumulating as erosion of the mountains deposited [[terrigenous]] sediments from the land into the sea.{{cite web |url=http://www.searchanddiscovery.net/documents/2006/06091eastern/abstracts/martin01.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080808134608/http://www.searchanddiscovery.com/documents/2006/06091eastern/abstracts/martin01.htm |archivedate=2008-08-08 |title=The Middle Devonian Hamilton Group Shales in the Northern Appalachian Basin: Production and Potential |accessdate=2008-04-02 |first=John P. | last = Martin | publisher= New York State Energy Research and Development Authority}} The Marcellus Shale was formed from the very first deposits in a relatively deep, sediment- and oxygen-starved ([[Anoxic sea water|anoxic]]), [[Trough (geology)|trough]] that formed parallel to the mountain chain.{{cite web|url=http://www.iogawv.com/RamsayBarrett-Shale.pdf |title=The Depositional Setting of The Marcellus Black Shale |accessdate=2008-04-02 |format=PDF |publisher=Independent Oil and Gas Association of West Virginia |work=Appalachian Producers Issues Seminar |first=Ramsay |last=Barrett |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080715110108/http://www.iogawv.com/RamsayBarrett-Shale.pdf |archivedate=July 15, 2008 }} These [[clastic]] fragments of rock were carried in [[braided stream]]s to the ancient [[Catskill Delta]], a [[river delta]] probably similar to the present day [[Niger Delta]] of Africa.{{cite journal | author = Mazzullo, S.J. | year = 1973 | title = Deltaic depositional environments in the Hamilton Group (middle Devonian, southeastern New York State) | journal = Journal of Sedimentary Research | volume = 43 | issue = 4 | pages = 1061–1071 | doi = 10.1306/74D728F1-2B21-11D7-8648000102C1865D }} Smaller particles remained [[suspension (chemistry)|suspended]] longer in this [[epeiric sea]], flowing offshore as [[turbidites]] in a slow but persistent underwater avalanche. They finally came to rest at the bottom of the Acadian [[foredeep]] in the [[Appalachian Basin]], hundreds of meters from shore, at depths that may have been {{convert|150|m|ft|-1|abbr=on}} or more beneath the surface.{{cite journal | author1 = Sageman, B.B. | author2 = Murphy, A.E. | author3 = Werne, J.P. | author4 = Ver Straeten, C.A. | author5 = Hollander, D.J. |author6 = Lyons, T.W. | year = 2003 | title = A tale of shales: The relative roles of production, decomposition, and dilution in the accumulation of organic-rich strata, Middle-Upper Devonian, Appalachian basin | journal = Chemical Geology | volume = 195 | pages = 229–273 | url = http://www.earth.northwestern.edu/research/sageman/PDF/03.Sageman_etal.pdf |format=PDF| doi = 10.1016/S0009-2541(02)00397-2 | bibcode = 2003ChGeo.195..229S }} Alternatively, the basin may have been as shallow as {{convert|50|m|ft|-1|abbr=on}} or less, if the warm water was sufficiently [[Stratification (water)|stratified]] so that oxygen rich surface water did not mix with the anoxic bottom water.{{cite book |author=Shultz, Charles H. |title=The geology of Pennsylvania |publisher=Pennsylvania Geological Survey |location=Harrisburg, Pa |year=1999 |pages= 125–126 |isbn=0-8182-0227-0 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} The Marcellus deposition produced a ''transgressive'' black shale, because it was deposited in deepening conditions when the basin floor dropped as the mountains rose up.{{cite book | title=Shales and mudstones | publisher=E. Schweizerbart | location=Stuttgart | year=1998 | pages= 109–128, | isbn=3-510-65181-2 | author = Ettensohn, F.R. | chapter = Compressional tectonic controls on Epicontinental black-shale deposition: Devonian-Mississippian examples from North America | chapterurl = http://cat.inist.fr/?aModele=afficheN&cpsidt=1809612 | accessdate = 2008-06-12 }} The dark shale [[facies]] of the Marcellus were formed from [[flysch]], a fine mud deposited in deep water; the deepening sea that deposited the Marcellus cut off the supply of [[carbonates]] that form limestone and the fine-grained flysch sediments buried the [[Onondaga Formation|Onondaga limestone]] beds.{{cite book | author = Patrick, K.J. | year = 2004 | title = Pennsylvania Caves and Other Rocky Roadside Wonders | publisher = Stackpole Books | isbn = 0-8117-2632-0 | page = 18 }} {{cite journal | author1 = Werne, J.P. | author2 = Sageman, B.B. | author3 = Lyons, T.W. | author4 = Hollander, D.J. | year = 2002 | title = An integrated assessment of a" type euxinic" deposit: Evidence for multiple controls on black shale deposition in the middle Devonian Oatka Creek formation | journal = American Journal of Science | volume = 302 | issue = 2 | pages = 110–143 | url = http://www.ajsonline.org/cgi/content/abstract/302/2/110 | accessdate = 2008-05-27 | doi = 10.2475/ajs.302.2.110 | bibcode = 2002AmJS..302..110W }} Organic matter, probably dominated by [[plankton]], also settled to the bottom, but the normal [[Decomposition|aerobic decay]] process was inhibited in the [[Hypoxia (environmental)|anaerobic]] environment thereby preserving the organic carbon.{{cite journal | author = McBride, P. | year = 2004 | title = Facies Analysis of the Devonian Gordon Stray Sandstone in West Virginia, M.S. Thesis | publisher = West Virginia University, Morgantown, West Virginia | page = 21 | url = https://eidr.wvu.edu/files/3403/McBride_Patrick_thesis.pdf |format=PDF}}{{dead link|date=October 2012}} {{cite journal | author = Lash, G.G. | year = 2008 | title = Pyrite Laminae In Black Shale-An Additional Source of Permeability In Unconventional Reservoirs | journal = 2008 Joint Meeting of the Geological Society of America, et al. | url = http://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2008AM/finalprogram/abstract_147721.htm | accessdate = 2008-07-14 }} Uranium was also incorporated in these organic muds syndepositionally, meaning it was deposited at the same time, rather than being introduced to the formation later.{{cite book |author1=Smol, J. P. |author2=Last, William M. |title=Tracking environmental change using lake sediments |publisher=Kluwer Academic |location=| volume=Vol. 2: Physical and Geochemical Methods |year=2001 |page= 191|isbn=1-4020-0628-4 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} The organic matter scavenged trace elements from the seawater,{{cite conference | author = Peucker-ehrenbrink, B. | year = 2001 | title = Dating Weathering of Organic-rich Shales with U-Series Disequilibrium | conference = Eleventh Annual V. M. Goldschmidt Conference | volume = 1 | publisher = | bibcode = 2001eag..conf.3781P | conferenceurl = }} including the [[redox]]-sensitive elements uranium, [[rhenium]], [[molybdenum]], [[osmium]], [[chromium]], and [[selenium]].{{cite web |url=http://www.whoi.edu/hpb/viewPage.do?id=1375&cl=8 |title= Black shale weathering |work=Bernhard Peucker-Ehrenbrink : Projects|publisher = Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution |accessdate=2008-07-13}} The Marcellus was deposited during the [[Evolutionary history of plants|development of land plants]], when atmospheric oxygen was increasing, resulting in a reduction of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, and the seawater where it was deposited.{{cite conference | first1 = Pat | last1 = Wilde | authorlink = | author2 = Quinby-Hunt, Mary S. | author3 = Lyons, Timothy W. | title = Sulfur Proxies in Type III Black Shales: Fe, Mn, Co, Cu, Ni, Zn, Sc | conference = 2005 Annual Meeting | pages = | date = 2005-10-13 | location = Salt Lake City, Utah | url = http://www.marscigrp.org/gsa05whl.ppt | id = Paper No. 76-7 | format = ppt | publisher = Geological Society of America | accessdate = 2008-06-21}} Named members of the Marcellus reflect two composite depositional sequences,{{cite journal | author = Desantis, M.K. | year = 2003 | title = Eifelian (early Middle Devonian) Depositional Sequences And Bioevents In Eastern Laurentia: Appalachian Basin-wabash Platform Comparisons | journal = 2003 Seattle Annual Meeting | publisher = Geological Society of America | volume = 35 | url = http://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2003AM/finalprogram/abstract_65945.htm | accessdate = 2008-05-26 | issue = 6 }} with a general coarsening upward cycle that continues into the base of the overlying Mahantango Formation. The interbedding of lighter shale and limestone members is attributed to relatively short-term oscillations in basin depth.{{cite book | author = Arthur, M.A. |author2=Sageman, B.B. | year = 2005 | chapter = Sea level control on source rock development: Perspectives from the Holocene Black Sea, the mid-Cretaceous Western Interior Basin of North America, and the Late Devonian Appalachian Basin | title = The Deposition of Organic Carbon-Rich Sediments: Models, Mechanisms and Consequences | pages = 35–59 | publisher = SEPM Society for Sedimentary Geology | isbn=1-56576-110-3 | url = https://www.sepm.org/publishing/toc/sp82toc.htm | archive-url = https://archive.is/20080229200239/https://www.sepm.org/publishing/toc/sp82toc.htm | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2008-02-29 }} Later deep water depositional sequences formed the overlying [[Brallier Formation]] and [[Harrell Formation]].{{cite book |author=VanDiver, Bradford B. |title=Roadside geology of Pennsylvania |publisher=Mountain Press Pub. Co |location=Missoula, Mont |year=1990 |pages= 86, 193 |isbn=0-87842-227-7 | series=Roadside Geology Series}} [[File:Catskill Magnafacies.svg|thumb|right|550px|Generalized geologic cross section of [[Catskill Delta]] [[facies|magnafacies]] across western [[Pennsylvania]] and eastern [[Ohio]]. [[Clastic]] deposits entered the [[Appalachian Basin]] from the east, where the resulting [[sedimentary rock]] is thickest.]] ===Age=== On the [[geological timescale]], the Marcellus occurs in the [[Middle Devonian]] epoch, of the [[Devonian]] [[Period (geology)|period]], in the [[Paleozoic]] [[Era (geology)|era]], of the [[Phanerozoic]] [[Eon (geology)|eon]]. Radiometric dating of a Marcellus sample from Pennsylvania placed its age at 384 million years old, and a sample from the bentonite at the top of the Onondaga at 390 ± 0.5 million years old.{{cite book |author1=Anstey, Robert L. |author2=Erwin, Douglas H. |title=New approaches to speciation in the fossil record |edition= |language= |publisher=Columbia University Press |location=New York |year=1995 |origyear= |pages= |quote= |isbn=0-231-08248-7 |oclc= |doi= |url= |accessdate=}} Relative age dating of the Marcellus places its formation in the Cazenovia subdivision of the [[Givetian]] [[faunal stage]], or 391.9 to 383.7 million years ago ([[Annum|Ma]]).{{cite web |url=http://paleodb.org/cgi-bin/bridge.pl?action=displayStrata&group_formation_member=Marcellus |title= Marcellus Formation, Group|accessdate=2008-04-03 |work=The Paleobiology Database}} The Union Springs member, at the base of the Marcellus in New York, has been dated to the end of the [[Eifelian]], the stage which immediately preceded the Givetian.{{cite book |author=Koutsoukos, Eduardo |title=Applied Stratigraphy (Topics in Geobiology) |publisher=Springer |location=Berlin |year=2005 |page= 70 |isbn=1-4020-2632-3}} Anoxic dark shales in the formation mark the [[Kačák Event]],{{cite journal|author=Menning, M. |author2=Alekseev, A.S. |author3=Chuvashov, B.I. |author4=Davydov, V.I. |author5=Devuyst, F.X. |author6=Forke, H.C. |author7=Grunt, T.A. |author8=Hance, L. |author9=Heckel, P.H. |author10=Izokh, N.G. | year = 2006 | title = Global time scale and regional stratigraphic reference scales of Central and West Europe, East Europe, Tethys, South China, and North America as used in the Devonian—Carboniferous—Permian Correlation Chart 2003 (DCP 2003) | journal = Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology | volume = 240 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 318–372 | doi = 10.1016/j.palaeo.2006.03.058 |display-authors=etal}} a late-[[Eifelian]]-[[Faunal stage|stage]] marine [[anoxic event]] also associated with an [[extinction event]].{{cite book |author=W. T. Kirchgasser |title=Devonian Events and Correlations : Special Publication no 278 |chapter=Recognising the Kacak Event in the Devonian terrestrial environment and its implications for understanding land-sea interactions|series=(Geological Society Special Publication) |publisher=Geological Society of London |location=London |year=2007 |pages= 133–155|isbn=1-86239-222-6 |oclc= |doi=}} In 2012, Read and Erikson also depicted the formation as Eifelian.[https://vtechworks.lib.vt.edu/bitstream/handle/10919/19078/Read%20and%20Eriksson.pdf?sequence=1 Paleozoic Sedimentary Successions of the Virginia Valley & Ridge and Plateau] [[File:Middle Dev strat Marcellus.png|thumb|right|550px|Generalized [[stratigraphy|stratigraphic]] nomenclature for the [[Middle Devonian]] strata in the [[Appalachian Basin]].]] ===Stratigraphy=== In the first [[Pennsylvania Geological Survey]], begun in 1836, [[Henry Darwin Rogers]] classified the Marcellus as the "Cadent Lower Black Slate" which he numbered "No. VIII b."{{cite book | author = Dana, J.D. | year = 1895 | title = Manual of Geology: Treating of the Principles of the Science with Special Reference to American Geological History | publisher = American book company | location = New York | edition = 4th ed.\ | chapter = Historical Geology | chapterurl = http://www.geology.19thcenturyscience.org/books/1896-Dana-ManGeol/htm/doc728.html | page = 728 | lccn = 04004705 }} In the first [[New York State Geological Survey]], also begun that year, [[James Hall (paleontologist)|James Hall]] established the term "Marcellus Shale" in his 1839 report titled "''Marcellus Shales in Seneca County.''"{{cite journal | author = Ellis, Mary | year = 1903 | title = Index to Publications of the New York State Natural History Survey and New York State Museum 1837–1902 | publisher = University of the State of New York | journal = New York State Museum Bulletin | page = 429 |location=Albany | issue = 66 | lccn = 03028299 }} Professor Hall also argued in 1839 against formulating geological names based on observed characteristics that may vary from place to place or need revision in the future, and in favor of location-based nomenclature where "the rock or group will receive its name from the place where it is best developed."{{cite book|title=The Texan Permian and Its Mesozoic Types of Fossils|first=Charles|last=white|year=1891|publisher=United States Geological Survey|location=Washington D.C.|page=401}} His arguments proved persuasive, and the location-based name for this, and many of the other group names he published based on exposures in New York, were adopted in the second Pennsylvania survey, and are now widely accepted. ====Overlying==== In the first New York survey, the Marcellus shale was placed below the Hamilton Group at the base of the Erie division of the New York system, but this taxonomy is obsolete. In current practice, the Marcellus Formation (abbr. Dm or Dms) is classified as the basal unit of the [[Hamilton Group]] (Dh), lying beneath the [[Mahantango Formation]] (Dmh) member of this group in Pennsylvania and Maryland. In New York, the Mahantango, also of Middle Devonian age, is further divided. There the Marcellus is separated from the overlying Skaneateles Formation, a more clastic and fossiliferous dark shale, by the thin Stafford or Mottville Limestone bed.{{cite journal | author1 = Martin, J.P. | author2 = Hill, D.G. | author3 = Lombardi, T.E. | year = 2004 | title = Fractured Shale Gas Potential In New York | journal = Northeastern Geology and Environmental Sciences | volume = 26 | issue = 1/2 | pages = 57–78 }} In West Virginia, the Marcellus may be separated from the brown shales of the Mahantango by occasional [[sandstone]] beds and [[concretions]],{{cite journal |author1=Boughton, Carol J. |author2=McCoy, Kurt J. | publisher = [[U.S. Geological Survey]] | year = 2006 | title = Hydrogeology, Aquifer Geochemistry, and Ground-Water Quality in Morgan County, West Virginia | url = http://pubs.usgs.gov/sir/2006/5198/ | id= Scientific Investigations Report 2006-5198 }} or it may lie directly below the younger [[Late Devonian]] [[Harrel Formation]] (or its lateral equivalents) because of a [[disconformity]],{{cite journal | author1 = Repetski, J.E. | author2 = Ryder, R.T. | author3 = Harper, J.A. | author4 = Trippi, M.H. | year = 2002 | title = Thermal maturity patterns (CAI and% Ro) in the Ordovician and Devonian rocks of the Appalachian basin in Pennsylvania | journal = US Geological Survey Open-File Report | page = 10 }} which represents a gap in the geological record due to a period of erosion or non-deposition. In eastern Ohio the Hamilton Group also lies disconformably beneath the Rhinestreet Shale Member of the [[West Falls Formation]], another transgressive black shale tongue with similar characteristics to the Marcellus. ====Underlying==== The Marcellus shale is typically found deposited on the limestone of the [[Onondaga Formation]] (Don), which extends down to the end of the [[Early Devonian]] period. The contact between them may be sharp, gradational, or erosional. In southwestern Ontario, Canada, north of [[Lake Erie]], the Marcellus overlies the Dundee Formation, a lateral equivalent of the Onondaga.{{cite web|url=http://www.mndm.gov.on.ca/mndm/mines/resgeol/southern/southwestern/geo_e.asp |title=Geology of the Southwestern District |work=Resident Geologist Program |accessdate=2008-04-02 |date=2004-05-21 |publisher=Ministry of Northern Development and Mines, Government of Ontario |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070922120056/http://www.mndm.gov.on.ca/mndm/mines/resgeol/southern/southwestern/geo_e.asp |archivedate=September 22, 2007 }} In Pennsylvania, the Marcellus forms a sharp [[Unconformity|conformable]] contact with the Onondaga's Selinsgrove Limestone member.{{cite web |url=http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/topogeo/openfile/midsusque.pdf |title= Preliminary Bedrock Geologic Map of the Middle Portion of the Susquehanna River Valley, Cumberland, Dauphin, And Perry Counties, Pennsylvania|year=2007|accessdate=2008-01-26|author1=Jackson, Margaret S. |author2=Hanley, Peter M. |author3=Sak, Peter B. |last-author-amp=yes |publisher=[[Pennsylvania Geological Survey]]|format=PDF|work=Open File Report OFBM-07-05.0}} A thin [[pyrite-carbonate]] bed is also found at the base of the Marcellus black shale in the exposures of south central Pennsylvania, above a thin calcerous green shale bed, which lies upon the Onondaga limestone. In eastern New York, the contact between the Marcellus and Onondaga (where present) is gradational.{{cite journal | author = Oliver Jr, W.A. | year = 1976 | title = Noncystimorph colonial rugose corals of the Onesquethaw and Lower Cazenovia Stages (Lower and Middle Devonian) in New York and adjacent areas | journal = Geological Survey Professional Paper | volume = 869 | pages = 1–156 }} In western New York, the Union Springs member of the Marcellus conformably overlies the Seneca member of the Onondaga Limestone, or the stratigraphically higher Cherry Valley Limestone member may rest directly and unconformably upon the Onondaga in the absence of the Union Springs shale.{{cite journal | author = Rickard, L.V. | year = 1984 | title = Correlation of the subsurface Lower and Middle Devonian of the Lake Erie region | journal = Bulletin of the Geological Society of America | volume = 95 | issue = 7 | pages = 814–828 | url = http://bulletin.geoscienceworld.org/cgi/content/abstract/95/7/814 | accessdate = 2008-04-03 | doi = 10.1130/0016-7606(1984)95<814:COTSLA>2.0.CO;2 | issn = 0016-7606 |bibcode = 1984GSAB...95..814R }} The local disappearance of units of the Onondaga suggests that its upper contact with the Marcellus can be erosional.{{cite web|url=http://www.searchanddiscovery.net/documents/2007/07022lash/images/Lash_AAPG_pg1_red.pdf|title=Influence of Basin Dynamics on Upper Devonian Black Shale Deposition, Western New York State and Northwest Pennsylvania|format=PDF|author=Lash, Gary|accessdate=2008-05-27|publisher=American Association of Petroleum Geologists}} In [[Erie County, New York|Erie County]] in western New York, both the upper and lower contact of the Marcellus are eroded away.{{cite journal|url=http://www.buffalocrushedstone.com/uploads/uploads5400/BCSDEISAsAccepted.pdf |format=PDF |title=Draft Environmental Impact Statement, Modification of Permit to Mine, Buffalo Crushed Stone Quarry |author=TVGA Consultants |publisher=New York State Department of Environmental Conservation |date=2007-08-29 |page=16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708103420/http://www.buffalocrushedstone.com/uploads/uploads5400/BCSDEISAsAccepted.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-08 |df= }} In eastern West Virginia the Marcellus overlies the Onesquethaw Group, consisting of the dark gray or green, calcitic, mostly nonfissil Needmore Shale, which grades westward into the Huntersville Chert. To the south and west, the Hamilton Group grades laterally into the Millboro Shale formation in southern West Virginia and Virginia, which grades into the lower part of the Chattanooga Shale of [[Tennessee]]. The Milboro is gradational with the underlying Needmore Formation shale.{{cite web|url=http://www.dmme.virginia.gov/DMR3/dmrpdfs/Giles_Geologic_Descriptions.pdf |title=Map Unit Descriptions |format=PDF |work= |publisher=Virginia Department of Mines, Minerals and Energy |date=2007-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080211213112/https://www.dmme.virginia.gov/DMR3/dmrpdfs/Giles_Geologic_Descriptions.pdf |archivedate=2008-02-11 |df= }} South of the [[Mason-Dixon line]], due to the difficulty in differentiating the Millboro and Needmore shales with the limited exposures available,{{cite book | author = Maryland Geological Survey | year = 1913 | title = Middle and Upper Devonian, text. | series = Reports Dealing with the Systematic Geology and Paleontology of Maryland | publisher = Johns Hopkins Press | location = Baltimore | pages = 40–48 | chapter = Adoption of the Romney Formation | chapterurl= https://books.google.com/books?id=169LAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA46 | lccn = gs13000808 }} and initial uncertainty in correlation with the New York survey, they were mapped as the Romney Formation, a unit containing all the Middle Devonian strata, named for an exposure at [[Romney, West Virginia]].{{cite book | author = Clark, W. B. |authorlink=William Bullock Clark| title = The geography of Maryland | series = Maryland Geological Survey | volume = vol. 10 | year = 1918 | location = Baltimore | publisher = Johns Hopkins Press}} The correlations were established by 1916 through tracing the New York exposures across Pennsylvania and Maryland into West Virginia, so under the principle of [[scientific priority]], the Romney classification is now obsolete; but its Marcellus and underlying Needmore shale members are still found grouped in an undifferentiated map unit (Dmn).{{cite journal |author1=Donovan, Joseph J. |author2=Eberhard Werner |author3=Dorothy J. Vesper |author4=Lacoa Corder | year = 2006 | title = Springs, source water areas, and potential for high-yield aquifers along the Cacapon Mountain anticline, Morgan County, WV | url = http://www.hrc.nrcce.wvu.edu/HRC3/HRC3-MorganCounty-Final%20Report2006.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2008-05-26 | publisher = [[West Virginia University]] | id = HRC-3 }} [[File:USGS 2006 1237 Fig7b.png|thumb|left|900px|Geologic cross section of upper to middle Devonian strata from [[Cherry Valley (town), New York|Cherry Valley]], [[New York (state)|New York]] southwest across the [[Allegheny Plateau]] and then along the [[Ridge-and-Valley Appalachians]] to [[Tennessee]]. Note the Marcellus grades up to the Milboro and Chattanooga black shales.]] {{Clear}} =====Tioga ash beds===== Tioga metabentonite or K-[[bentonite]]–stratigraphic unit about {{convert|.6|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} thick that consists of several discrete, relatively thin [[volcanic ash]] falls–is also included at the base of the Marcellus in eastern Pennsylvania.{{cite web |url=http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/topogeo/map1/explanation.pdf |format=PDF|title= Explanation of Geologic Units |accessdate=2008-01-26 |work=|publisher=Pennsylvania Geological Survey}} In 1843 it was described without being named by Hall,{{cite journal |author=Collins, H.R. |year= 1979 | title = Devonian Bentonites in Eastern Ohio: GEOLOGIC NOTES | doi = 10.1306/2F9181AD-16CE-11D7-8645000102C1865D | journal = AAPG Bulletin | volume = 63 }} and more than 100 years passed before it was eventually named for the [[natural gas field]] in [[Tioga County, Pennsylvania]],{{cite journal | author = Dennison, J.M. |author2=Textoris, D.A. | year = 1970 | title = Devonian tioga tuff in Northeastern United States | journal = Bulletin Volcanologique | volume = 34 | issue = 1 | pages = 289–294 | doi = 10.1007/BF02597791 |bibcode = 1970BVol...34..289D }} where it was encountered when [[borehole|drilling]] [[Oil well|gas wells]]. It is a regional stratigraphic marker, used by geologists to identify the Marcellus,{{cite journal|author=Scheetz, B.E. |author2=Ellsworth, C.J. |date=2007-07-31 |title=Preliminary Assessment of Acid Producing Rock on Future PENNDOT Construction, Final Report |url=http://www.mautc.psu.edu/docs/PSU-2005-05.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2008-06-14 |id=FHWA-PA-2007-022-510401-05; PTI 2007–53 |publisher=[[National Technical Information Service]] (U.S.) |pages=41–42 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100708071702/http://www.mautc.psu.edu/docs/PSU-2005-05.pdf |archivedate=July 8, 2010 }} and correlate laterally equivalent strata. Difficulty in correctly identifying the more than 80 different ash falls during the Devonian period, collected in 15 or more beds, has also led to many miscorrelations. From Virginia to New York the Tioga is widely distributed, running across the central and northern parts of the Appalachian basin, an areal extent exceeding {{convert|265000|km2|sqmi|-3|abbr=on}}. [[Explosive eruption]]s associated with the [[Acadian orogeny]] originating near present-day central Virginia released the ash into the atmosphere. It was dispersed across the [[Appalachian Basin|Appalachian]], [[Michigan Basin|Michigan]], and [[Illinois Basin|Illinois]] Basins by the southern [[trade winds]], because this area was in the southern hemisphere during the Devonian period.{{cite book | author = Dennison, J.M. | year = 1986 | title = Tioga Bentonite in the Appalachian Basin: Final report | publisher = U.S. Department of Energy | id = DOE/ET/12139-T2 }} The volcanic origin of the ash is evidenced by its distinctive [[mineralogy]]–the ash was deposited directly upon the water, so its angular quartz grains differ from the clastic sediments rounded through the erosion process that carries them to the sea. As the volcanic ash settled to the bottom, it was [[mixture|admixed]] with these terrigenous components, producing a distinctive lithology in the sedimentary rock. [[File:Marcellus I80 MP307.jpg|thumb|right|Marcellus exposure along [[Interstate 80]] in eastern Pennsylvania where the formation is thickest.]] The Tioga may appear in the formation as a gray, brown, black, or olive bed, or parting,{{cite web |url=http://igs.indiana.edu/geology/structure/compendium/html/comp1lb8.cfm |title=Tioga Bentonite Bed |first = John B.|last=Droste|author2=Robert H. Shaver | year = 1997 |work=Compendium of Paleozoic Rock-Unit Stratigraphy in Indiana — A Revision |accessdate=2008-06-12}} consisting of coarse crystal [[tuff]] or tuffaceous shale, thinly laminated, with sand-sized mica flakes.{{cite web |url=http://www.mgs.md.gov/esic/geo/lgdalleg.html |title=Geologic Map Legends : Allegheny Plateau and Valley and Ridge|work =Geologic Map of Maryland | year =1968| publisher = Maryland Geological Survey |accessdate=2008-06-12}} The Tioga ash bed zone consists of eight ash beds labeled according to their stratigraphic order from A (oldest) to H (youngest),{{cite journal | author = Kaufmann, B. | year = 2006 | title = Calibrating the Devonian Time Scale: A synthesis of U—Pb ID—TIMS ages and conodont stratigraphy | journal = Earth-Science Reviews | volume = 76 | pages = 175–190 | doi = 10.1016/j.earscirev.2006.01.001 |bibcode = 2006ESRv...76..175K | issue = 3–4 }}{{cite conference | author1 = Way, J.H. | author2 = Smith, R.C. | author3 = Roden, M. | year = 1986 | title = Detailed correlations across 175 miles of the Valley and Ridge of Pennsylvania using 7 ash beds in the Tioga Zone | conference = 51st Annual Field Conference of Pennsylvania Geologists | booktitle = Selected geology of Bedford and Huntington Counties | pages = 55–72 | publisher = U.S. Geological Survey }} and another bed known as the Tioga middle coarse zone.{{cite journal | author = Ver Straeten, C.A. | year = 2004 | title = K-bentonites, volcanic ash preservation, and implications for Early to Middle Devonian volcanism in the Acadian orogen, eastern North America | journal = Bulletin of the Geological Society of America | volume = 116 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 474–489 | doi = 10.1130/B25244.1 |bibcode = 2004GSAB..116..474V }} Its basal beds are found within the uppermost beds of the Onondaga Limestone or Needmore Shale, and the uppermost ash bed within the lowermost part of the Marcellus or Millboro Shale.{{cite web |url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2006/1237/of2006-1237.pdf|format=PDF|title= Assessment of Appalachian Basin Oil and Gas Resources: Devonian Shale–Middle and Upper Paleozoic Total Petroleum System |author1=Milici, Robert C. |author2=Swezey, Christopher S. |year=2006|accessdate=2008-04-05 |work=Open-File Report Series 2006-1237| publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]}} In western New York state, the Tioga Ash Bed B marks the boundary between the Moorehouse and Seneca Members of the Onondaga Formation,{{cite map|title=New York State Geological Highway Map |year=1990|author=Isachsen, Y. W.|author2=T. D. Mock |author3=R. E. Nyahay |author4=W. B. Rogers |series=Educational Leaflet No. 33 | publisher = New York State Museum |url=http://geology.about.com/library/bl/maps/n_statemap_NYexplan.htm|id=Plate 3, Legend for the Geologic Map}} but in the central part of the state, and the southern part of the basin, the ash beds are actually in the Marcellus.{{cite journal | author = Koch Ii, W.F. | year = 1981 | title = Brachiopod community paleoecology, paleobiogeography, and depositional topography of the Devonian Onondaga Limestone and correlative strata in eastern North America | journal = Lethaia | volume = 14 | issue = 2 | pages = 83–103 | doi = 10.1111/j.1502-3931.1981.tb01909.x }} This indicates that deposition of the Marcellus there began earlier,{{cite journal |author=Martin, R.L. |year=2002 |title=Taxonomic Revision and Paleoecology of Middle Devonian (Eifelian) Fishes of the Onondaga, Columbus and Delaware Limestones of the eastern United States |accessdate=2008-07-07 |publisher=West Virginia University |url=http://kitkat.wvu.edu:8080/files/2728/Martin_Robert_dissertation.pdf |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060907001801/http://kitkat.wvu.edu:8080/files/2728/Martin_Robert_dissertation.pdf |archivedate=2006-09-07 |df= }} since the ash beds represent a single epoch in geologic time. ====Thickness==== Maximum thickness of the Marcellus ranges from {{convert|270|m|ft|-1|abbr=on}} in New Jersey, to {{convert|12|m|ft|-1|abbr=on}} in Canada. In West Virginia, the Marcellus Formation is as much as {{convert|60|m|ft|-1|abbr=on}} thick. In extreme eastern Pennsylvania, it is {{convert|240|m|ft|-1|abbr=on}} thick, thinning to the west, becoming only {{convert|15|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} thick along the [[Ohio River]], and only a few feet in [[Licking County, Ohio]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dispatch.com/live/content/science/stories/2008/03/11/Sci_shale.ART_ART_03-11-08_B4_A99I7HO.html?print=yes |title=Low down, rich and stingy |first=Kevin |last=Mayhood |accessdate=2008-04-04 |date=2008-03-11 |work=The Columbus Dispatch |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523030900/http://www.dispatch.com/live/content/science/stories/2008/03/11/Sci_shale.ART_ART_03-11-08_B4_A99I7HO.html?print=yes |archivedate=2011-05-23 |df= }} The thinning, or [[Stratigraphy|stratigraphic]] convergence, from east to west is caused by decreasing grain size in the [[clastic rock|clastic]] deposits, which entered the basin from the east.{{cite journal | author = Dennison, J.M. |author2=Hasson, K.O. | year = 1976 | title = Stratigraphic cross section of Hamilton Group (Devonian) and adjacent strata along south border of Pennsylvania |journal=AAPG Bulletin |volume= 60 | issue = 2 | pages = 278–287 | doi= 10.1306/83D922BC-16C7-11D7-8645000102C1865D | url = http://search.datapages.com/data/doi/10.1306/83D922BC-16C7-11D7-8645000102C1865D | accessdate = 2008-05-03 }} The beds finally "pinch out" westward because deposition was limited by the Cincinnati Arch,{{cite web|url=http://www.dnr.state.oh.us/Portals/10/pdf/BurgerReport.pdf |format=PDF |title=Geologic Assessment of the Burger Power Plant and Surrounding Vicinity for Potential Injection of Carbon Dioxide |first=Lawrence H. |last=Wickstrom |author2=Ernie R. Slucher |author3=Mark T. Baranoski |author4=Douglas J. Mullett |publisher=Ohio Geological Survey |year=2008 |accessdate=2008-06-21 |location=Columbus, Ohio |id=Open-File Report 2008-1 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081231180506/http://www.dnr.state.oh.us/Portals/10/pdf/BurgerReport.pdf |archivedate=2008-12-31 |df= }}{{cite book | author = Roen, J. |author2=Walker, B. | year = 1996 | title = The Atlas of Major Appalachian Gas Plays | publisher = West Virginia Geological and Economic Survey | id = Publication V-25 }} the bulge that formed the west shore of the basin. Where the formation is relatively thick, it is divided into several members, and as the formation continues to thicken to the east, these members are further divided. Some workers chose to classify the Marcellus as a subgroup, and classify some of the members as separate formations. {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="10" style="float:right;" | {| style="border-top:1px solid gray; border-bottom:1px solid gray; border-right:1px solid gray; border-left:1px solid gray;" | {| border="0" cellpadding="0" style="text-align: left;" | {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+'''Members of the Marcellus Formation from West to East in New York''' |- !
