named members from west to east across central New York state.{{cite web |url=http://www.searchanddiscovery.net/documents/2007/07101nyahay/index.htm | author = Nyahay, Richard |author2=James Leone |author3=Langhorne Smith |author4=John Martin |author5=Daniel Jarvie |title= Update on the Regional Assessment of Gas Potential in the Devonian Marcellus and Ordovician Utica Shales in New York|format=PDF |publisher =American Association of Petroleum Geologists | date =September 2007 |work= 2007 AAPG Eastern Section Meeting, September 16–18, Lexington, Kentucky|id= Search and Discovery Article #10136 (2007)|accessdate=2008-05-25}}{{cite journal | author = Grasso, T.X. | year = 1968 | title = A new coral bed in the Hamilton Group (Middle Devonian) of central New York | journal = Journal of Paleontology | volume = 42 | issue = 1 | pages = 84–87 | jstor=1302130 }} |} |} |} ====Named members==== A local Purcell limestone member, {{convert|15|to|30|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} of inter-bedded calcitic shale and limestone, divides the Marcellus in eastern Pennsylvania. The Purcell is stratigraphically equivalent to the Cherry Valley Limestone member in New York,{{cite journal | author = Stein Jr, W.E. | year = 1982 | title = Iridopteris eriensis from the Middle Devonian of North America, with Systematics of Apparently Related Taxa | journal = Botanical Gazette | volume = 143 | issue = 3 | page = 401 | doi = 10.1086/337316 | jstor=2474838 }} a [[bioclast]]ic [[packstone]], consisting of skeletal limestones, with shaly intervals between its lower massive limestone layer, thick nodular limestone/[[marlstone]], and upper limestone layer. Other named members include the Bakoven Shale, Cardiff Shale, Chittenango shale, Solsville sandstone, Union Springs shale and limestone, and Stony Hollow shale and limestone.{{cite web |url=http://paleodb.org/cgi-bin/bridge.pl?action=displayStrata&group_hint=Hamilton&formation_hint=Marcellus%20Shale&group_formation_member=Stony%20Hollow |title= Stony Hollow Member|accessdate=2008-05-23 |work=The Paleobiology Database}} The Union Springs, Cherry Valley, and Oatka Creek merge beneath Lake Erie, into the Bell Shale, Rockport Quarry Limestone, and Arkona Shale of Ontario. The Union Springs is an organic-rich, pyritiferous, thinly bedded, blackish gray to black shale with mudstone concretionary layers,{{cite web |url=http://bingweb.binghamton.edu/~kwilson/Devonian/DevSites/Chestnut_Street/Chestnut_Street.htm |title=Lower Marcellus Formation – the Chestnut Street Road Cut |first=Karl A. |last =Wilson | publisher = State University of New York at Binghamton |work= New York Paleontology|accessdate=2008-05-23|date=2006-09-27}} and thin silt bands at the bottom. To the east, it becomes the Bakoven Member, a darker, less organic shale with fewer limestone layers. To the west the Union Springs beds thin, with its upper limestones merging with the overlying [[calcareous]] Cherry Valley Member. A regional unconformity appears in western New York, as the Union Springs lenses in and out, and then reappears in northwest Pennsylvania and northeast Ohio between the Onondaga and Cherry Valley. In Western and central New York, the uppermost member is the dark grey to black organic-rich Oatka Creek shale. Unlike the other Devonian shales in this region, the gray shale at the top of the Oatka Creek thickens gradually to the west, as well as the east,{{cite web|url=http://www.searchanddiscovery.net/documents/2007/07022lash/images/Lash_AAPG_pg2_red.pdf|title=Influence of Basin Dynamics on Upper Devonian Black Shale Deposition, Western New York State and Northwest Pennsylvania, Page 2|format=PDF|author=Lash, Gary|accessdate=2008-05-27|publisher=American Association of Petroleum Geologists}} where it divides into the Cardiff member lying above the Chittenango member in central New York. Organic-rich, fissile, sooty black shales make up the Chittenango Member. At the base of the Chittenango,{{cite journal | author = Kasprak, A.H. | year = 2008 | title = Nowakia (dacryoconarida) In The Halihan Hill Bed (oatka Creek Formation, New York) | url = http://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2008NE/finalprogram/abstract_134728.htm | publisher = Geological Society of America | accessdate = 2008-05-26 }} above the Bierne Member shale,{{cite journal | author = Bartholomew, A. |author2=Schramm, T. | year = 2007 | title = Faunal Turnover Between Two Ee Subunits: Investigating The Timing Of Large-scale Faunal Turnover In The Latest Eifelian Of Eastern North America | journal = 2007 GSA Denver Annual Meeting | url = http://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2007AM/finalprogram/abstract_132498.htm | accessdate = 2008-05-26 }} lies the Halihan Hill Bed, a highly [[Bioturbation|bioturbated]] bioclastic limestone. Further east, the homogeneous Cardiff divides into the Bridgewater, Solsville, and Pecksport shale members, from base to top. The Bridgewater is a fissile dark silty shale with relatively rare fossils. A thin concretionary zone lies above, then the Solsville grades from a gray calcareous shale, to sandy siltstones and fine sandstones at the top, with the gray shale of the Pecksport shale and siltsone overlying it.{{cite web |url=http://bingweb.binghamton.edu/~kwilson/Devonian/DevSites/SwampRd/swamprd.htm |title=The Marcellus Formation — The Swamp Road Roadcut |first=Karl A. |last =Wilson | publisher = State University of New York at Binghamton |work= New York Paleontology|accessdate=2008-05-23|date=2007-03-31}} In south central Pennsylvania, the Marcellus is mapped with three members, from top to base: The Mahanoy Member (Dmm), a dark gray to grayish black silty shale and siltstone; the Turkey Ridge Member (Dmt), an olive to dark-gray fine to medium grained sandstone; and the Shamokin Member (Dms), a dark gray to grayish black fissile carbonaceous shale that is calcareous in places near the base.{{cite map|title=Geologic Map of the Mifflintown Qd., PA |url=http://www.libraries.psu.edu/emsl/guides/pageomaps/A126_1.html |id=A126 |scale=1:24,000 |author1=Conlin, Richard R. |author2=Hoskins, Donald M. |publisher=[[Pennsylvania Geological Survey]], Fourth Series |cartography=[[United States Geological Survey]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071203022334/http://www.libraries.psu.edu/emsl/guides/pageomaps/A126_1.html |archivedate=December 3, 2007 }} The Turkey Ridge is commonly mapped in the Mahantango Formation,{{cite map|author=MacLachlan, D.B., hoskins, D.M., Payne, D.F.|year=1995|title=Bedrock Geology of the Freeburg 7.5 minute Quadrangle, Snyder County, Pennsylvania|series=Open-File Reports|url=http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/topogeo/pub/openfile/pdfs/of95_04_freeburg.pdf|format=PDF|id= ORF 95-04|publisher=[[Pennsylvania Geological Survey]], Fourth Series|cartography=[[United States Geological Survey]]}} or included in the Montebello Formation (Dmot),{{cite map|title=Geologic Map of the Loysville Qd., PA |url=http://www.libraries.psu.edu/emsl/guides/pageomaps/A127_1.html |id=A127 |scale=1:24,000 |author=Miller, John T. |publisher=[[Pennsylvania Geological Survey]], Fourth Series |cartography=[[United States Geological Survey]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071203022339/http://www.libraries.psu.edu/emsl/guides/pageomaps/A127_1.html |archivedate=December 3, 2007 }} and only the Shamokin correlates with the Marcellus on adjacent map sheets.{{cite map|title=Geologic Map of the Millerstown 15 Minute Quadrangle, PA |url=http://www.libraries.psu.edu/emsl/guides/pageomaps/A136_5.html |id=A136, Plate 5 |year=1976 |scale=1:24,000 |author=Hoskins, Donald M. T. |publisher=[[Pennsylvania Geological Survey]], Fourth Series |cartography=[[United States Geological Survey]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071204015837/http://www.libraries.psu.edu/emsl/guides/pageomaps/A136_5.html |archivedate=December 4, 2007 }} In extreme eastern Pennsylvania, the Broadhead Creek member, a dark gray silty shale with dark gray shaly limestone concretions, appears above the Stony Hollow and Union Springs, in a layer up to {{convert|275|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} thick.{{cite map|title=Geologic Map of the Stroudsburg Qd., PA, NJ |url=http://www.libraries.psu.edu/emsl/guides/pageomaps/GQ1047.html |id=GQ1047 |year=1973 |scale=1:24,000 |author=Epstein, Jack |publisher=[[Pennsylvania Geological Survey]], Fourth Series |cartography=[[United States Geological Survey]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060901093048/http://www.libraries.psu.edu/emsl/guides/pageomaps/GQ1047.html |archivedate=September 1, 2006 }} [[File:Marcellus Cephalopod 1896-Dana-ManGeol-Fig917.png|thumb|upright|Illustration of a [[Cephalopod]] ''([[Goniatites]] vanuxemi)'' fossil from the Marcellus Formation.{{cite book | author = Dana, J.D. | year = 1896 | title = Manual of Geology: Treating of the Principles of the Science with Special Reference to American Geological History | publisher = American Book Company | edition = 4th | page = 599 }}]] ===Fossils=== There are relatively sparse inclusions of fossilized marine [[fauna]] found in the Marcellus, but these fossils are still important to paleontology. For example, the Marcellus contains the oldest known diverse collection of thin-shelled [[mollusks]] still having well preserved shell microstructure.{{cite journal | author = Carter, J.G. |author2=Tevesz, M.J.S. | year = 1978 | title = Shell microstructure of a Middle Devonian (Hamilton Group) bivalve fauna from central New York | journal = Journal of Paleontology | volume = 52 | issue = 4 | pages = 859–880 | jstor=1303906 }} It is also where [[goniatites]], an extinct shelled swimmer similar to a squid, make their first appearance in the fossil record.{{cite book |title=Notes on the Geology of Onondaga County, NY : Embracing a Short Description of the Various Eras, Periods and Groups|first=Philip F. | last =Schneider | year = 1894| location = Syracuse, NY|page = 37}} Life on land also enters the fossil record in the Marcellus, with the trunks of branchless [[conifer]] trees that floated out to sea to be preserved in the black shale. Marcellus fossils include specimens of the large clam-like [[brachiopod]] Spinocyrtia.{{cite web |url=http://www.nyps.org/field.htm |work= New York Paleontological Society Field Trips |title=Devonian Seas of Central New York : Syracuse Area, New York |accessdate=2008-05-25}} External molds of [[crinoid]]s, plant-like animals related to starfish also known as "sea lilies,"{{cite web|url=http://www.igsb.uiowa.edu/Browse/flood93/flood93.htm |title=Flood of 1993 Uncovers Devonian Sea Floor |work=Iowa Geology |publisher=Iowa Department of Natural Resources |year=1994 |accessdate=2008-06-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080616080943/http://www.igsb.uiowa.edu/Browse/flood93/flood93.htm |archivedate=2008-06-16 |df= }} are found in the formation,{{cite book |author=Burns, Jasper |title=Fossil Collecting in the Mid-Atlantic States: With Localities, Collecting Tips, and Illustrations of More Than 450 Fossil Specimens |publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press |location=Baltimore |year=1991 |page=96 |isbn=0-8018-4145-3}} with the molds partially filled with [[limonite]]; brachiopod and [[bivalve]] (clam) molds have also been found in the shale.{{cite journal | author = Pabian, R.K. |author2=Strimple, H.L. | year = 1976 | title = Middle Devonian crinoids from western Maryland | journal = Journal of Paleontology | volume = 50 | issue = 4 | pages = 759–762 | jstor=1303668 }} Small conical [[Tentaculite|tentaculitid]]s are commonly found in the Chittenango Member. The Halihan Hill bed contains [[styliolinid]]s and macrofauna including brachiopods, coral-like [[bryozoan]]s, small bivalves and [[gastropod]]s (snails), incorporated after the [[faunal stage|faunal turnover]] when [[Emsian]] and [[Eifelian]] Schoharie/Onondaga fauna were replaced by the [[Givetian]] Hamilton fauna. The Solsville member contains well preserved bivalves, gastropods, and brachiopods. These shellfish lived in the [[benthic zone]] at the bottom of marginal marine to open marine environments that existed west of the ancient [[Catskill Delta]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ncsu.edu/kenanfellows/2002/hhill/chapt3/chapt3.html |title=Chapter 3 Fossils and Geologic Time |work= The Big Dig|publisher = [[North Carolina State University]], Kenan Fellows Program|author= Hill, Heidi|accessdate=2008-05-25 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071025085454/http://www.ncsu.edu/kenanfellows/2002/hhill/chapt3/chapt3.html |archivedate = October 25, 2007}} The fossil record in this member shows the base was dominated by [[deposit feeder]]s, while the upper layers were dominated by [[filter feeder]]s. This can be correlated to the lithology: the finer sediments of the shales at the base of this member would contain abundant adherent organic matter for deposit feeders, but would tend to foul the gills of filter feeders when suspended; the coarser sediments of the sandstones at the top would have contained less organic matter to support deposit feeders. Below the Solsville, at the base of the Otsego in eastern New York, a [[Coral reef|coral bed]] is found; another coral bed can be seen at the top of the Marcellus near [[Berne, New York]].{{cite journal |doi=10.2475/ajs.249.10.705 |author=Oliver, W.A. |date=October 1, 1951 |title=Middle Devonian coral beds of central New York |journal=American Journal of Science |volume=249 |issue=10 |pages=705–728 |url=http://ajsonline.org/cgi/content/abstract/249/10/705 |accessdate=2008-06-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724231318/http://ajsonline.org/cgi/content/abstract/249/10/705 |archivedate=2011-07-24 |df= |bibcode=1951AmJS..249..705O }} A diverse, eel-like [[conodont]] fauna occurs in the limestone of the Cherry Valley Member,{{cite book |author= Over, D.J. |author2=Klapper, G. |author3=Murphy, M.A. |author4=Talent, J.A. | year = 1997 | title = Paleozoic Sequence Stratigraphy, Biostratigraphy, and Biogeography: Studies in Honor of J. Granville ('Jess') Johnson | publisher = [[Geological Society of America]] | isbn = 0-8137-2321-3 | page = 152 }} which is also known for its rich [[nautiloid]] and goniatite [[cephalopod]] fauna. Originally named the ''Goniatite Limestone'',{{cite journal | author = Yochelson, E.L. |author2=Hlavin, W.J. | year = 1985 | title = Coleolus curvatus Kindle (" Vermes") from the Cleveland Member of the Ohio Shale, Late Devonian (Famennian) of Ohio | journal = Journal of Paleontology | volume = 59 | issue = 5 | pages = 1298–1304 | jstor=1305019}} it produces their fossilized remains with shells that can be larger than {{convert|.3|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} across. It also contains the "Cephalopod Graveyard" in the [[Schoharie Valley]] of eastern New York, an unusual accumulation of abundant coiled and straight shells of several types of large adult cephalopods. This bed lacks juvenile fossils, indicating that if their behavior was similar to modern squid, this may have been an area where these Devonian cephalopods reproduced and died.{{cite web |url=http://www.nysm.nysed.gov/education/teacher/ancient_life_text.html |title=Ancient Life of New York : A Billion Years of Earth History |date= September 2003 |work= |publisher= New York State Museum |accessdate=2008-05-26}} This [[stratigraphic]] interval also provides an excellent example of incursion [[epibole]]s, which are sudden appearances and disappearances of fossil [[Taxon|taxa]] in relatively thin sections of the rock unit. In the Cherry Valley, the taxa do not reoccur; instead each thin concretionary limestone bed contains different species of goniatites.{{cite book | author = Brett, C.E. |author2=Baird, G.C. | year = 1997 | title = Paleontological Events: Stratigraphic, Ecological, and Evolutionary Implications | publisher = Columbia University Press | isbn = 0-2310-8250-9 | page = 269 }} The Cherry Valley and Union Springs also contain well-preserved [[anarcestida]].{{cite book |author1=Davis, R. Michael |author2=Landman, Neil H. |author3=Tanabe, Kazushige |title=Ammonoid paleobiology |publisher=Plenum Press |location=New York |year=1996 |page= 644|isbn=0-306-45222-7 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} ==Economic impact== {{update|section|date=November 2010}} ===Natural Gas=== {{main|Marcellus natural gas trend}} [[File:Marcellus Shale Gas Play.png|thumbnail|Producing gas wells in the Marcellus Shale gas play]] The Marcellus natural gas trend, which encompasses 104,000 square miles and stretches across Pennsylvania and West Virginia, and into southeast Ohio and upstate New York, is the largest source of natural gas in the United States, and production was still growing rapidly in 2013. The Marcellus is an example of [[shale gas]], natural gas trapped in low-permeability shale, and requires the well completion method of [[hydraulic fracturing]] to allow the gas to flow to the well bore. The surge in drilling activity in the Marcellus Shale since 2008 has generated both economic benefits and environmental concerns—and thus, considerable controversy. ===Iron=== At the base of the Marcellus, in the [[pyrite]]-[[carbonate]] bed between the carbonaceous black shale and a green calcareous shale bed, pyrite, carbonate, and groundwater reacted to form [[gossan]] [[iron oxide]] and [[gypsum]].{{cite journal | url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3790/is_200707/ai_n19434226/pg_10 |author = Feldmann, R.M. |author2=Schweitzer, C.E. |author3=Redman, C.M. |author4=Morris, N.J. |author5=Ward, D.J. | year = 2007 | title = New Late Cretaceous Lobsters From The Kyzylkum Desert Of Uzbekistan|journal=Journal of Paleontology | volume = 81 | issue = 4 |pages = 701–713 | doi = 10.1666/pleo0022-3360(2007)081[0701:NLCLFT]2.0.CO;2 | issn=0022-3360 }} As far as the ground water necessary for the conversion could penetrate, the pyrite-carbonate was converted to a usable brown [[hematite]] [[iron ore]] along the outcrops and near the bedrock surface.{{cite book | author = Lesley, J.P. | year = 1892 | title = A summary description of the Geology of Pennsylvania | publisher = Pennsylvania Geol. Survey, 2d, Final Rept. | volume = Vol. II | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=TEA4AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA1233&lpg=PA1233 }} The Marcellus iron ore was actively mined in south Central Pennsylvania from its discovery in the late 18th century, until it was supplanted by the rich ore beds of the [[Iron Range]] of [[Minnesota]] in the early 20th century.{{cite book | author = Swank, J.H. | year = 1892 | title = History of the Manufacture of Iron in All Ages, and Particularly in the United States From Colonial Times to 1891. | publisher = Ayer Publishing | location = Philadelphia | isbn = }} The ore was easily located and worked from shallow pits and shafts, but once the usable upper deposits were removed, or if a mine shaft entered the bed too far below the surface, only unusable unconverted pyritic deposits were found. Hematite ore was converted to [[pig iron]] in [[charcoal]]-fired stone [[blast furnace]]s that were constructed throughout the [[Juniata River]] region near the workable ore deposits from the Marcellus and other formations. Iron products from this area, known as "Juniata Iron," were produced during the period between the [[American Revolution]] and the [[American Civil War]]. These blast furnaces were important to the economy of the region at the time,{{cite book | author = Ashburner, Charles A. | chapter = A measured section of the Paleozoic Bucks of Central Pennsylvania, from the top of the Allegheny River Coal Series, down to the Trenton Limestone or the Lower or Cambro-Silurian System | year = 1876 | publisher = American Philosophical Society | title = Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society Held at Philadelphia for Promoting Useful Knowledge | volume = Vol. XV, No. 96 }} but the [[cold blast]] stone furnaces typically employed were inefficient, and consumed significant amounts of timber from the nearby hardwood forests, which ultimately led to their demise.{{cite journal | author = Schallenberg, R.H. |author2=Ault, D.A. | year = 1977 | title = Raw Materials Supply and Technological Change in the American Charcoal Iron Industry | journal = Technology and Culture | volume = 18 | issue = 3 | pages = 436–466 | doi = 10.2307/3103901 | publisher = Technology and Culture, Vol. 18, No. 3 | jstor=3103901 }} A typical furnace used {{convert|2400|kg|lb|abbr=on}} of hematite ore and {{convert|7.3|m3|impbu|abbr=on}} of charcoal to produce {{convert|910|kg|lb|abbr=on}} of pig iron, and could produce several thousand pounds per day, which required logging more than {{convert|4000|m2|acre|0|abbr=on}} of forest daily.{{cite web |url=http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/stateparks/parks/littlebuffalo/littlebuffalo_history.aspx |title= Little Buffalo State Park: Park History |publisher = Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources|work= Pennsylvania State Parks|accessdate=2008-06-21}} The ore from the Marcellus varied in thickness, becoming unworkably thin, and even disappearing altogether in places between the workable beds. The quality of the ore also varied, and it was not always profitable to [[smelting|smelt]], as several furnaces built near iron ore mines in the Marcellus were abandoned before the ore and timber resources used to fuel them became scarce.{{cite book | author = Lesley, J. P. | year = 1859 | title = The Iron Manufacturer's Guide to the Furnaces, Forges and Rolling Mills of the United States | publisher = J. Wiley | location = New York | page = 651 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=NSJDAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA651 | lccn = 06022651 }} Ore found interbedded in the black slaty shale contained a relatively high proportion of carbon which was burned in the furnace, and [[sulfur]], which produced a usable but "[[red-short]]" iron.{{cite book | author = Platt, Franklin. | year = 1881 | title = The Geology of Blair County | series = Report of Progress | publisher = Board of commissioners for the Second geological survey | location = Harrisburg | lccn = gs07000757 }} Red-short iron has the undesirable properties of oxidizing more easily, and a tendency to crack, especially when heated to a red-hot state.{{cite book | author = Crookes, W. |author2=Röhrig, E. | year = 1869 | title = A practical treatise on Metallurgy | volume = Vol. II | publisher = Longmans Green | location = London | page = 695 }} In some locations in Pennsylvania the quality of the ore was quite good, with relatively deep veins containing 45% iron, and very low sulfur. In Virginia, the Marcellus ore occasionally contained [[zinc]], which produced a characteristic green flame in the furnace as it was consumed, but deposited a hard mass of impure [[zinc oxide]] known as [[cadmia]], which built up over time near the top of the flue, and had to be removed periodically to keep it unobstructed.{{cite journal | author = Firmstone, H. | year = 1879 | title = On a Deposit of Cadmia in a Coke Blast Furnace | journal = Transactions of the American Institute of Mining Engineers | volume = VII | pages = 93–94 | publisher = American Institute of Mining Engineers }} ====Iron pigments==== Drainage that reacted with the pyrite inclusions also deposited a form of [[bog iron]] near several outcrops of the Marcellus. In the 19th century, iron ore from these deposits was used as a mineral paint pigment. After being heated in a kiln and finely ground, it was mixed with [[linseed oil]], and used to paint exterior wood on barns, covered bridges, and railroad cars. In addition to the bog iron, at several sloped locations in eastern Pennsylvania brown hematite was found lying on the Marcellus bedrock buried beneath the soil. These deposits were also excavated and used for mineral paint during that time. A bed of hematite paint ore is also found almost directly below the Marcellus, but it is actually part of the underlying Oriskany Formation. ====Chalybeate==== Iron rich "ferruginous waters" emanating from [[chalybeate]] springs near the base of the Marcellus in [[Bedford, Pennsylvania]] were believed to have healing powers by Native Americans. The [[Bedford Springs Hotel]] was a [[mineral spa]] built in 1802 around a series of mineral springs, including one of these, its "iron spring". The Chalybeate Springs Hotel, built nearby in 1851 around three other mineral springs including another chalybeate spring,{{cite web |url=http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WM1054 |title=Chalybeate Springs Hotel — U.S. National Register of Historic Places|work=Waymarking.com |accessdate=2008-10-09}} became a "resort for invalids".{{cite book|title=The Geology of Bedford and Fulton Counties|first =John James | last = Stevenson|publisher=The board of Commissioners for the 2d. Geological Survey (of Pennsylvania)|year= 1882| location=Harrisburg|pages = 342–343|lccn=gs07000758}} The iron-rich waters were prescribed for [[anemia]] and related complications. Both of these mineral springs contain iron in the form of dissolved [[iron carbonate]], which gives these waters a "slightly inky taste".{{cite book|title=Diseases of the stomach | first = John Conrad |last = Hemmeter|page= 327|publisher = Blakiston | year = 1902}} ===Other uses=== The Marcellus has also been used locally for shale [[Construction aggregate|aggregate]] and common [[Fill dirt|fill]], although the pyritic shales are not suitable for this purpose because of acid rock drainage and volumetric expansion.{{cite journal | author = Doden, A.G. |author2=Gold, D.P. |author3=Hoover, S.E. |author4=Scheetz, B.E. |author5=Ellsworth, C.J. | year = 2008 | title = Road Bed And Building Heave From Alteration Of Sulfide And Sulfate Minerals | url = http://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2008NE/finalprogram/abstract_134913.htm | publisher = [[Geological Society of America]] | accessdate = 2008-05-04 }} In the 19th century, this shale was used for walkways and roadways,{{cite book | author = Underwood, L.M. | year = 1879 | title = The Geological Formations Crossed by the Syracuse and Chenango Valley Railroad: Together with a Sketch of the Hydrography and Valley Formations of Madison and Onondaga Counties |publisher=Standard Pub. Co. |location= Syracuse, N.Y. | series = Ph. D. Thesis, [[Syracuse University]] | page = 8 }} and was considered superior "[[road metal]]" because the fine grained fragments packed together tightly, yet drained well after a rain. The dark slaty shales may have the necessary [[Cleavage (geology)|cleavage]] and hardness to be worked, and were quarried for low grade roofing [[slate]] in eastern Pennsylvania during the 19th century. The slates from the Marcellus were inferior to the [[Martinsburg Formation]] slate quarried further south, and most quarries were abandoned, with the last significant operation in Lancaster County. The Marcellus black slate was also quarried in Monroe County, Pennsylvania, for [[Chalkboard|school slates]] used by students in 19th-century rural schools. Carbonaceous shales, such as the Marcellus, are a possible target for [[carbon capture and storage]] for [[mitigation of global warming]]. Because carbon [[Adsorption|adsorbs]] [[carbon dioxide]] (CO2) at a greater rate than [[methane]] (CH4), carbon dioxide injected into the formation for geological [[CO2 sequestration|sequestration]] could also be used to recover additional [[natural gas]] in a process analogous to [[enhanced coal bed methane recovery]], but the practical value of this theoretical technique is not yet known. Scientists believe that adsorption would allow sequestration at shallower depths than [[Absorption (chemistry)|absorption]] in deep saline formations, which must be at least {{convert|800|m|ft|-2|abbr=on}} below the surface to maintain liquid CO2 in a [[Supercritical fluid|supercritical state]]. ===Engineering issues=== [[File:Marcellus Shale Gas Drilling Tower 1 crop.jpg|thumb|right|A horizontal drilling rig for natural gas in the Marcellus formation in eastern [[Lycoming County, Pennsylvania]].]] Exposures from [[cut and fill]] road construction in Virginia and Pennsylvania have resulted in localized [[acid rock drainage]] due to [[oxidation]] of the pyrite inclusions.{{cite journal | author1 = Orndorff, Z.W. | author2 = Lee Daniels, W. | year = 2004 | title = Evaluation of acid-producing sulfidic materials in Virginia highway corridors |journal=Environmental Geology |volume= 46 | issue = 2 | pages = 209–216 | url = http://www.springerlink.com/index/8C50W05J4CR2JY2Y.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2008-05-03 | doi = 10.1007/s00254-004-1027-y }} The newly exposed shale on the cut face weathers rapidly, allowing air and water into the unexcavated rock, resulting in acidic [[surface runoff]] after precipitation events.{{cite journal | author = Smith, M.W. | author2=Varner, J.P. | author3=Mital Jr, J.P. | author4=Sokoloski, D.J. | year = 2006 | title = Remediation Of Acid Rock Drainage From Highway Construction In The Marcellus Shale, Mifflin County, Pennsylvania | journal = Geological Society of America Abstracts with Programs | volume = 38 | issue = 2 | page = 33 | url = http://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2006NE/finalprogram/abstract_100515.htm | accessdate = 2008-05-04 }} Acidic runoff disrupts [[aquatic ecosystem]]s, and highly [[acidic soil]] [[Soil contamination|contaminated]] by this runoff will not support vegetation, which is unsightly, and can lead to problems with [[soil erosion]]. Natural decomposition of the shale into smaller fragments can affect [[slope stability]], necessitating shallower slopes that require more material be disturbed in cut and fill work, exacerbating the acid rock drainage problem. The cut material cannot be used as fill beneath roads and structures due to volumetric expansion, compounding the problem. The Tioga ash beds contain [[bentonite]] [[clay]] which presents a [[landslide]] hazard in the unexcavated rock as well. Damage to structures constructed on fill consisting of pyritic Marcellus shale has been caused by expansion from [[sulfuric acid]] (H2SO4) runoff reacting with the [[calcite]] (CaCO3) in the shale to produce [[gypsum]] (CaSO4), which has double the [[molar volume]].{{cite conference | author1 = Hoover, S.E. | author2 = Wang, M.C. | author3 = Dempsey, B. | year = 2004 | title = Structural damage induced by pyritic shale | conference = Fifth International Conference on Case Histories in Geotechnical Engineering, April 13–17, 2004, New York, N. Y.[[Proceedings]][electronic resource] | pages = 7 | publisher = | url = http://www.csa.com/partners/viewrecord.php?requester=gs&collection=TRD&recid=2004112611434CE&recid=20049978EQ | conferenceurl = }} Other [[sulfate]] minerals that can be produced by reactions with pyrite include [[anhydrite]], [[melanterite]], [[rozenite]], [[jarosite]], and [[alunite]]. The reactions have generated a heave pressure on the order of 500 kPa (10,000 pounds per square foot), but may be able to generate four times this pressure   enough to heave [[Foundation (engineering)|foundations]] in a 5-story building. [[Limestone]], which is used to neutralize the acid drainage, can actually exacerbate the expansion problem by promoting sulfate–sulfate reactions that form the minerals [[thaumasite]] and [[ettringite]], which have even higher molar volumes. Drilling [[borehole]]s through the Hamilton Group shales in the subsurface can be problematic. The Marcellus has a relatively low [[density]], and these shales may not be chemically compatible with some [[drilling fluid]]s. The shale is relatively fragile, and may fracture under pressure, causing a problem in circulating the drilling fluid back up through the borehole known as lost circulation. The formation may also be under-pressurized, further complicating the drilling process. ==See also== *[[Geology of New Jersey]] *[[Geology of Pennsylvania]] **[[List of mapped rock formations in {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox research institute |name = National Balloon Facility |motto = |logo = |image = TIFR balloon facilityogo.png |established = 1961 |research_field = [[Research balloon]]ing |head_label = Chairperson |head = Prof. Devendra Ojha |staff = |budget = |operating_agency = {{hlist |[[TIFR]] |[[ISRO]]}} |affiliations = |address = TIFR Balloon Facility,
ECIL PO |city = [[Hyderabad, Telangana|Hyderabad]] |province = {{nowrap|[[Telangana]]}} |country = [[India]] |zipcode = 500 062 |website = [http://www.tifr.res.in/~bf/index.html tifr.res.in/~bf/index.html] }} The '''National Balloon Facility''', also known as the TIFR Balloon Facility, is a stratospheric-balloon launch base under the joint management of the [[Tata Institute of Fundamental Research]] (TIFR) and the [[Indian Space Research Organisation]] (ISRO). This institute is located at [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]] near [[Electronics Corporation of India Limited]] (ECIL).{{Cite web|url=http://stratocat.com.ar/bases/31e.htm|title=Stratospheric balloon launch bases and sites|publisher=StratoCat|date=12 October 2010|accessdate=19 October 2010}} Being the only major balloon facility in the world close to the [[Magnetic dip#Explanation|geomagnetic equator]], this facility is extensively used by researchers from all over the world.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tifr.res.in/~bf/about%20us.html|title=NBF History|publisher=TIFR|accessdate=19 October 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031029142857/http://www.tifr.res.in/~bf/about%20us.html|archivedate=29 October 2003|df=dmy-all}} ==History== Ballooning activity in India was prompted by research into atmospheric exploration and cosmic ray studies. During the 1940s, Dr. [[Homi J. Bhabha]] of TIFR started sending balloons up to an altitude of 25 km to study secondary cosmic radiation. Due to unique geographic reasons [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]] was selected for stratospheric balloon launches. After various diplomatic meetings arrangements were made by US and Indian organisations to jointly launch balloons from Hyderabad. The first launch had support of Air Force Cambridge Research Laboratory (AFCRL) and TIFR. The launches were carried out from two locations. US balloons were launched from [[Begumpet Airport]] and Indian balloons from [[Osmania University]] Campus. The first balloon was launched on 2 February 1961. During the first stage of the facility's operation, forty balloons were launched. After five years all the facilities were consolidated at Osmania University and under management of [[National Center for Atmospheric Research]] & TIFR and around 170 balloons were launched. After a few years with increasing demands for balloon flights, a relatively low population density and proximity to the geomagnetic equator, a permanent site at Hyderabad near ECIL was selected. However, presently due to rapid development this facility is today surrounded by several population settlements: by the [[Cherlapally Central Jail]] in the east; [[Kamala Nagar, Hyderabad|Kamala Nagar]] in the west; and [[Electronics Corporation of India]] Ltd. in the south.{{Cite web|url=http://stratocat.com.ar/bases/31e.htm|title=Stratospheric balloon launch bases and sites|publisher=StratoCat|date=12 October 2010|accessdate=19 October 2010}} ==Activities== The campus contains a complete balloon manufacturing facility. The institute conducts balloon-based scientific experiments in X-ray and [[Infrared Astronomy]], and in [[Aeronomy]]. Balloons from this facility are launched twice in a year, i.e. in summer and winter. NBF also regularly monitors and analyses local weather at [[tropospheric]] and [[stratospheric]] altitudes, required for making decisions about balloon launches. Under the High Altitude Balloon Development Project, a 61,000m³ indigenously developed balloon penetrated into the Mesosphere on 7 January 2014, for the first time in India. Until that time, only balloons from USA and Japan had accomplished this feat.[http://www.tifr.res.in/~bf/HAA_Record.html HAA Records] ==See also== * [[Balloons for X-ray astronomy]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Research institutes in Telangana}} [[Category:Research institutes in Hyderabad, India]] [[Category:Atmospheric sciences]] [[Category:Tata Institute of Fundamental Research]] [[Category:Atmospheric sounding]]

The '''Natural History Museum of Armenia''' represents Armenia's unique nature and its diversity. The museum was reopened in 2004.<ref>[https://armenpress.am/arm/news/397620 Երևանում վերաբացվեց ՀՀ բնության պետական թանգարանը]</ref>
== History == During the [[Soviet]] period, an anti-religion museum was opened in 1952 which was later transformed into a museum of natural sciences and in 1960 renamed as The Natural History Museum of Armenia. In 1999 the museum was relocated in another building. From 2000 to 2004 with the patronage of Bella and Levon Aharonyan, two [[Iranian Armenians|Iranian-Armenian]] benefactors, the building of the museum was reconstructed and opened to the public with its new exhibition.
== Exhibition == The museum is home to over 6000 objects, only one-third of which are temporarily or primarily put on display. In four rooms, rare types of flora and fauna are exhibited. The museum also presents the personal collection of the Aharonyan family.
The objects in the museum represent the diversity of nature in Armenia. The main exhibition contains photos related to zoology, botany, geology and plastic arts. replicas of mammals, reptiles, birds, amphibious animals, fish, insects, and arachnid as well as skulls, skins, shells, pieces of trees, samples of herbarium, animal or plant fossils, useful extracted materials, oil paintings, drawings etc.
== Events == The museum holds exhibitions and occasional events aiming to increase environmental awareness and active participation in offering solutions for environmental problems. Many of the animals in the museum are registered in the [[IUCN]] [[Red List of Threatened Species]].
== The Natural History Museum of Armenia == Since February 27, 2003, The Natural History Museum of Armenia operates according to the constitution of the republic of Armenia.<ref>[http://www.arlis.am/DocumentView.aspx?DocID=10159/ ՀՀ կառավարության Որոշում, 10 հոկտեմբերի 2002 թվականի N 1638-Ն]</ref> The goal of the museum, аs a non-commercial organization, is to raise awareness and knowledge regarding environmental issues and positively influence the accomplishment of environmental programs.
The organization fulfills various types of enterprises such as the following: * Designing micro museums and spaces for plants and animals indoors * Organizing parallel exhibitions to those of the museum such as exhibitions of decorative fish or birds. * Increasing the number of the endangered species in Armenia, so as to return them to the nature * Growing decorative plants and nurturing herbal plants for exhibition purposes.
== Branches == The museum has active branches in [[Shirak Province|Shirak]] ([[Gyumri]]) and [[Ararat Province|Ararat]] (Qukasav) regions.
== Address == * Number 34, Tigran Mex Avenue, Yerevan, Armenia

{{short description|A measure of the amount of cloudiness or haziness in sea water caused by individual particles that are too small to be seen without magnification}} {{refimprove|date=September 2013}} [[Image:Pre-Hurricane Bob Ocean Turbidity.jpg|thumb|Visualisation of the Ocean Turbidity of the ocean just before [[Hurricane Bob]] (August 14, 1991)]] '''Ocean turbidity''' is a measure of the amount of cloudiness or haziness in sea water caused by individual particles that are too small to be seen without magnification. Highly [[turbidity|turbid]] [[ocean]] waters are those with a large number of scattering [[particulate]]s in them. In both highly absorbing and highly scattering [[water]]s, visibility into the water is reduced. The highly scattering (turbid) water still reflects a lot of light while the highly absorbing water, such as a [[blackwater river]] or lake, is very dark. The scattering particles that cause the water to be turbid can be composed of many things, including [[sediment]]s and [[phytoplankton]].
==Measurement==
There are a number of ways to measure ocean turbidity, including autonomous remote vehicles, [[shipcasts]] and satellites.
From a [[satellite]], a proxy measurement of the water turbidity can be made by examining the amount of [[reflectance]] in the visible region of the [[electromagnetic spectrum]]. For the [[Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer]] (AVHRR), the logical choice is band 1, covering [[wavelengths]] 580 to 680 [[nanometre]]s, the [[orange (colour)|orange]] and [[red]]. In order to make derived products that are comparable over [[time]] and [[space]], an [[atmospheric correction]] is required. To do this, the effects of [[Rayleigh scattering]] are calculated based on the satellite viewing angle and the [[solar zenith angle]] and then subtracted from the band 1 [[radiance]]. For an [[Particulate|aerosol]] correction, band 2 in the near infrared is used. It is first corrected for Rayleigh scattering and then subtracted from the Rayleigh corrected band 1. The Rayleigh corrected band 2 is assumed to be aerosol [[radiance]] because no return signal from water in the near [[infrared]] is expected since water is highly absorbing at those wavelengths. Because bands 1 and 2 are relatively close on the electromagnetic spectrum, we can reasonably assume their aerosol radiances are the same.
In these images the turbidity is quantified as the percent reflected light emerging from the water column in a range of 0 to 8 percent. The reflectance percentage can be correlated to [[attenuation]], [[Secchi disk depth]] or total suspended solids although the exact relationship will vary regionally and depends on the [[optical]] properties of the water. For example, in [[Florida Bay]], 10% reflectance corresponds to a sediment concentration of 30 milligram/litre and a Secchi depth of 0.5 metre. These relationships are approximately [[linear]] so that 5% reflectance would correspond to a sediment concentration of approximately 15 milligram/litre and a Secchi depth of 1 metre. In the [[Mississippi River]] plume regions these same reflectance values would represent sediment concentrations that are about ten times or more higher.
==Hurricanes==
As one would expect, the majority of these images reveal large increases in turbidity in the regions where a hurricane has made landfall. The increases are primarily due to sediments that have been resuspended from the shallow bottom regions. In areas near shore some of the signal may also be due to sediments [[erosion|eroded]] from [[beach]]es as well as from sediment laden river plumes. In some cases a post-hurricane [[phytoplankton bloom]] due to increased [[nutrient]] availability may perhaps be detectable.
The examination of the turbidity after the passing of a hurricane can have potentially many uses for coastal resource management including:
* identifying regional "hot spots" where the erosion could be expected to be most severe * estimating the total sediment concentration that has been mobilized by the hurricane * determining the spatial extent of the sediment mobilization * identifying the extent and contribution of river plumes * assessing and predicting potential [[ecosystem]] impacts
With regard to these uses, determining the regions of high turbidity will allow managers to best decide on response strategies as well as help ensure that post-hurricane resources are most effectively utilized.
==Interpreting images==
Only a small fraction of the light incident on the ocean will be reflected and received by the satellite. The probability for a [[photon]] to reflect and exit the ocean decreases exponentially with length of its path through the water because the ocean is an absorbing medium. The more ocean a photon must travel through, the greater its chances of being absorbed by something. After absorption, it will eventually become part of the ocean's heat reservoir. The absorption and scattering characteristics of a water body determine the rate of vertical light attenuation and set a limit to the depths contributing to a satellite signal. A reasonable rule of thumb is that 90 percent of the signal coming from the water that is seen by the satellite is from the first attenuation length. How deep this is depends on the absorption and scattering properties of both the water itself and other constituents in the water. For wavelengths in the near infrared and longer, the penetration depth varies from a metre to a few [[micrometre]]s. For band 1, the penetration depth will usually be between 1 and 10 metres. If the water has a large turbidity spike below 10 metres, the spike is unlikely to be seen by a satellite.
For very shallow clear water there is a good chance the bottom may be seen. For example, in the [[Bahamas]], the water is quite clear and only a few metres deep, resulting in an apparent high turbidity because the bottom reflects a lot of the band 1 light. For areas with consistently high turbidity signals, particularly areas with relatively clear water, part of the signal may be due to bottom reflection. Normally this will not be a problem with a post-hurricane turbidity image since the [[storm]] easily resuspends enough sediment such that bottom reflection is negligible.
[[Cloud]]s are also problematic for the interpretation of satellite derived turbidity. Cloud removal [[algorithm]]s perform a satisfactory job for [[pixel]]s that are fully cloudy. Partially cloudy pixels are much harder to identify and typically result in false high turbidity estimates. High turbidity values near clouds are suspect.

[[File:The World as 100 People.png|thumb|Compilation of graphs from the organization, showing the overall global percentages of the last two centuries, in six factors: Extreme poverty, democracy, basic education, vaccination, literacy, child mortality.]] '''Our World In Data''' (OWID) is an [[Electronic publishing|online publication]] that presents empirical research and data that show how [[living conditions]] around the world are changing. The web publication on [[International development|global development]] uses interactive [[Data visualization|data visualisations]] (charts and maps) to present the research findings on development that explain the causes and consequences of the observed changes. The aim is to show how the world is changing and why.
The publication is developed at the [[University of Oxford]] and authored by social [[historian]] and development economist [[Max Roser]]. It covers a wide range of topics across many academic disciplines: Trends in [[health]], [[Hunger|food provision]], the [[Economic growth|growth]] and [[Economic inequality|distribution of incomes]], [[violence]], [[Human rights|rights]], [[war]]s, [[culture]], [[energy use]], [[education]], and [[environmental change]]s are empirically analysed and visualised in this web publication.
Covering all of these aspects in one resource makes it possible to understand how the observed long-run trends are interlinked. The research on global development is presented to the audience of interested readers, journalists, academics, and policy people. The articles cross-reference each other to make it possible for the reader to learn about the drivers of the observed long-run trends. For each topic the quality of the data is discussed and, by pointing the visitor to the sources, this website works as a database of databases – a meta-database.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ourworldindata.org/about/|title=About — Our World in Data|website=ourworldindata.org|access-date=2016-03-08}}</ref>
Our World In Data is made available as a [[public good]]: * The entire publication is freely available, * the data published on the website is available for download, * all visualizations created for the web publication are made available under a [[Creative Commons license|Creative Commons]] license, * and the tools to publish Our World In Data and to create the visualizations are free to use (available [[Open-source software|open source]] on [[GitHub]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/OurWorldInData/our-world-in-data-grapher|title=OurWorldInData/our-world-in-data-grapher|website=GitHub|access-date=2016-03-09}}</ref> Our World in Data is currently financed entirely through small individual donations from readers of the publication.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tilt.com/tilts/help-save-ourworldindataorg|title=Save OurWorldInData.org|website=www.tilt.com|access-date=2016-03-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309110606/https://www.tilt.com/tilts/help-save-ourworldindataorg|archivedate=2016-03-09|df=}}</ref> The website is used widely in the media.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ourworldindata.org/media-coverage/|title=Media Coverage of OurWorldInData.org — Our World in Data|website=ourworldindata.org|access-date=2016-03-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151104060054/http://ourworldindata.org/media-coverage/|archivedate=2015-11-04|df=}}</ref> Authors like [[John Green (author)|John Green]] and [[Steven Johnson (author)|Steven Berlin Johnson]] use it for their work. It is used in teaching by economists, historians, and international development experts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://chrisblattman.com/2016/01/25/links-i-liked-284/|title=Chris Blattman blog|website=Chris Blattman|access-date=2016-03-08}}</ref>
Tina Rosenberg emphasised in ''[[The New York Times]]'' that Our World In Data presents a “big picture that’s an important counterpoint to the constant barrage of negative world news”. [[Steven Pinker]] placed Roser’s Our World In Data on his list of his personal “cultural highlights”<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2015/aug/23/on-my-radar-steven-pinker-psychologist-author|title=On my radar: Steven Pinker’s cultural highlights|last=Observer|first=Steven Pinker/the|date=2015-08-23|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-03-08}}</ref> and explained in his article on 'the most interesting recent scientific news' why he considers Our World In Data so very important.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.edge.org/response-detail/26616|title=Human Progress Quantified – Edge answer by Steven Pinker|website=www.edge.org|access-date=2016-03-08}}</ref>

The '''petroleum industry in Syria''' forms a major part of the [[economy of Syria]]. According to the [[International Monetary Fund]], before the [[Syrian Civil War]], oil sales for 2010 were projected to generate $3.2 billion for the Syrian government and accounted for 25.1% of the state's revenue.<ref name=IMF>{{cite book|title=IMF Country Report No. 10/86 |date=March 2010 |page=17|url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/scr/2010/cr1086.pdf|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref>
Syria is a relatively small oil producer, that accounted for just 0.5% of the global production in 2010,<ref name=ReutersEnergy>{{cite news|title=Factbox: Syria's energy sector|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/08/14/us-syria-oil-idUSTRE77D15V20110814|accessdate=18 August 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=14 August 2011|first=Daniel|last=Fineren}}</ref><ref name=PBReview>{{cite web|title=BP Statistical Review of World Energy June 2011|url=http://www.bp.com/assets/bp_internet/globalbp/globalbp_uk_english/reports_and_publications/statistical_energy_review_2011/STAGING/local_assets/pdf/statistical_review_of_world_energy_full_report_2011.pdf|publisher=British Petroleum. pp. 6-8|accessdate=18 August 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615211258/http://www.bp.com/assets/bp_internet/globalbp/globalbp_uk_english/reports_and_publications/statistical_energy_review_2011/STAGING/local_assets/pdf/statistical_review_of_world_energy_full_report_2011.pdf|archive-date=15 June 2011}}</ref> falling to less than 0.05% by 2016.<ref>https://www.bp.com/content/dam/bp/en/corporate/pdf/energy-economics/statistical-review-2017/bp-statistical-review-of-world-energy-2017-full-report.pdf</ref> Although Syria is [[List of countries by oil production|not a major oil exporter]] by Middle Eastern standards, oil is a major component of the Syrian economy. Syria's oil sector has been hit by the Civil War and international sanctions imposed on Syria.
Syria’s two biggest oil companies are the [[Syrian Petroleum Company]] (SPC), which is owned by the Syrian Ministry of Petroleum and Mineral Resources, and Al-Furat Petroleum Company, which is 50% owned by SPC and the other 50% foreign owned. The joint venture currently includes SPC with 50%, [[Royal Dutch Shell|Anglo-Dutch Shell]] with 32%, and the remainder held by Himalaya Energy Syria, a consortium of [[China National Petroleum Company]] and [[India]]'s [[Oil and Natural Gas Corporation]].<ref name=EIA/> As of December 2011 Shell has suspended operations in Syria due to EU sanctions.<ref name=ft021211>{{cite web|title=Shell to quit Syria after EU extends sanctions|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/bc9dae8a-1cd1-11e1-a134-00144feabdc0.html#axzz24klfkSfR|publisher=Financial Times|date=2 December 2011|accessdate=29 August 2012}}</ref> Another important consortium is Deir Ez Zor Petroleum Company, owned by SPC and [[France]]'s [[Total S.A.|Total]]. Total suspended operations in the country from December 2011.<ref name=wsj290812>{{cite web|title=Total: To Stop Operations With General Petroleum Corp Of Syria|url=https://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20111205-710369.html|publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=5 December 2011|accessdate=29 August 2012}}</ref> A more recent entrant is the [[United Kingdom]]'s Gulfsands Petroleum. As of February 2012, Gulfsands has suspended its Syrian operations due to EU sanctions.<ref name=gulfsands>{{cite web|title=Block 26, Syria|url=http://www.gulfsands.com/s/Syria.asp|publisher=Gulfsands Petroleum|accessdate=28 August 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120912090400/http://www.gulfsands.com/s/Syria.asp|archivedate=12 September 2012|df=}}</ref>
== Geography == [[File:Syria Oil Map.gif|thumb|Map of Syrian oil fields and pipelines]] Syria is the only significant crude oil producing country in the [[Eastern Mediterranean]] region, which includes [[Jordan]], [[Lebanon]], [[Israel]] and the [[Palestinian territories]]. According to the ''Oil and Gas Journal'', Syria had {{convert|2500000000|oilbbl|m3}} of petroleum reserves as of 1 January 2010.<ref name=EIA>{{cite web|title=Country Analysis Brief: Syria|url=http://www.eia.gov/countries/cab.cfm?fips=SY|publisher=US Energy Information Agency|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref> Syria's known oil reserves are mainly in the eastern part of the country in the [[Deir ez-Zor Governorate]] near its border with [[Iraq]] and along the [[Euphrates River]], and a number of smaller fields are located in the center of the country.<ref name=OBG95>{{cite book|title=The Report: Syria 2011|year=2011|publisher=Oxford Business Group|isbn=1-907065-34-2|page=96|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oDz9juos_tkC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Report:+Syria+2011+By+Oxford+Business+Group#v=onepage&q=oil%20french%20mandate&f=false}}</ref> In 2010, Syria produced around {{convert|385000|oilbbl|m3}} per day of crude oil.<ref name=IMF/><ref name=PBReview/> Oil production has stabilized after falling for a number of years, and is poised to turn around as new fields come online. In 2008, Syria produced {{convert|5.3|e9m3|cuft}} of natural gas, and two years later in 2010, it increased production to {{convert|7.8|e9m3|cuft|abbr=on}}.<ref name=PBReview22/> While much of its oil is exported to Europe, Syria's natural gas is used in reinjection for [[enhanced oil recovery]] and for domestic electricity generation.<ref name=EIA/>
Although Syria produces relatively modest quantities of oil and gas, its location is strategic in terms of regional security and prospective energy transit routes.<ref name=EIA/> The first section of the [[Arab Gas Pipeline]] to enter Syria, totalling {{convert|600|km|mi}} through Syria, starts at the Jordan–Syria border in the south, connecting to Tishreen and [[Deir Ali]] power stations.<ref name="Downstream08">{{cite web | url=http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=8761 | title=Syria Completes First Stage of Arab Gas Pipeline | publisher=Downstream Today | date=18 February 2008 | accessdate=15 December 2015 | author=Xinhua News Agency}}</ref> This was subsequently extended to connect to Deir Ammar power station in Lebanon and [[Baniyas]] in Syria.<ref name="DTLebanon">{{cite news | url=http://downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=18758 | title=Lebanon Receives Egypt Gas To Run Power Plant | work=Downstream Today | date=20 October 2009 | agency=McClatchy-Tribune Information Services | accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref> A further section was planned to continue up to the Turkish border,<ref name="Downstream08" /> but the ongoing civil war is expected to further delay this connection.<ref name="Rzaveya">{{cite book | url=http://www.oxfordenergy.org/wpcms/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/NG-82.pdf | title=Natural Gas in the Turkish Domestic Energy Market: Policies and Challenges | author=Rzaveya, Gulmira | date=February 2014 | pages=38–39}}</ref>
== History == [[File:حقل نفط رميلان.jpg|thumb|A [[pumpjack]] in Syria's Rumeilan oil fields]] Syrian oil exploration first began in 1933 during the French Mandate by the [[Iraq Petroleum Company]] (a consortium made up of [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]], [[BP]], [[Exxon-Mobil]], [[Total S.A.|Total]], and Gulbekian), which after unsuccessfully drilling eleven wells, gave up hope of finding any oil in Syria. In 1949, James W. Menhall (1881-1974), an independent oil producer from Illinois, United States, was approached by Syrian President [[Shukri al-Quwatli]] to come to Syria to prospect for oil. His James W. Menhall Drilling Company was awarded a concession on 17 May 1955 by unanimous vote of the Syrian parliament and started drilling in April 1956.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} In September 1956, Menhall discovered the [[Karatchok]] oil field with over 1 billion barrels of reserves. Six consecutive wells were drilled, each producing in excess of {{convert|4000|oilbbl|m3}}.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} Menhall was just commencing preparations to drill the adjoining [[Rmelan|Rumeilan]] oil field (with over 500 million barrels of reserves) when, on 5 October 1958, President [[Gamal Abdel Nasser|Nasser]] of Egypt, as President of the [[United Arab Republic]], expropriated Menhall's concession and confiscated his equipment and three drilling rigs without compensation.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} The Syrian government, under the Baath Party leadership, has since refused to consider any compensation.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} The Syrian oil industry took off in 1968, when the Karatchok oil field began production after a pipeline connecting it to the [[Homs]] refinery was completed, although Syria did not begin exporting oil until the mid-1980s.<ref name="USState">{{cite web | url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/3580.htm | title=Background Note: Syria | publisher=US State Department | accessdate=18 August 2011 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817013711/http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/3580.htm | archive-date=17 August 2011}}</ref>
In 2009, Syria's net [[List of countries by oil exports|petroleum exports]] were estimated to be {{convert|148000|oilbbl/d|m3/d|abbr=on}}.<ref name=USGeoSurvey>{{cite web|last=Taib|first=Mowafa|title=2009 Minerals Yearbook: Syria|url=http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/country/2009/myb3-2009-sy.pdf|publisher=US Geological Survey|accessdate=23 August 2011}}</ref> All oil exports are marketed by [[Sytrol]], Syria's state oil marketing firm, which sells most of its volumes under 12-month contracts. Before the imposition of EU sanctions, Syrian crude oil exports went mostly to the [[European Union]], in particular [[Germany]], [[Italy]], and [[France]], totaling an estimated {{convert|137400|oilbbl/d|m3/d|abbr=on}} in 2009, according to [[Eurostat]].<ref name=EurostatOil>{{cite web|title=Imports (by country of origin) - oil - annual data|url=http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=nrg_123a&lang=en|publisher=Eurostat|accessdate=23 August 2011}}</ref> In 2010, the European Union as a whole spent $4.1 billion on Syrian oil imports.<ref name=EUOil>{{cite web|title=Registration of Crude Oil Imports and Deliveries in the European Union 2010|url=http://ec.europa.eu/energy/observatory/oil/doc/import/coi/eu-coi-2010-01-12.pdf|publisher=European Commission Directorate-General for Energy|accessdate=21 August 2011}}</ref>
Local exporters of oil in Syria include the [[Altoun Group]] in Maraba, Damascus, Syria,<ref>[http://www.international.gc.ca/media/aff/news-communiques/2012/05/18b.aspx Canada Tightens Sanctions Against Assad Regime]. International.gc.ca.</ref> formed in 1968.<ref>[https://altoun.en.ec21.com/company_info.html Altoun Group-Company Introduction ]</ref> It is owned by [[Salim Altoun]], who has been on an EU sanctions list since May 2012.<ref>https://othersuns.wordpress.com/2012/05/15/syria-salim-altoun-and-the-altoun-group-added-to-the-eu-sanction-list/</ref>
The [[Syrian Civil War]] broke out in 2011 and is ongoing. In the same year, Syria’s major trading partners imposed international sanctions on Syrian oil and financial system, devastating the Syrian oil industry, adding to the devastation of the civil war.
==Challenges== [[File:Syria oil exports by destination country 2010.gif|thumb|right|Syria oil exports by destination country in 2010 (note that as of 2012, all countries on this chart no longer trade oil with Syria due to sanctions against the country)]] Besides the Civil War and the imposition of international sanctions, Syria's oil sector faces a number of challenges, including a decline in output and production resulting from technological problems and a depletion of oil reserves. Syria's rate of oil production has decreased steadily from a peak of close to {{convert|610000|oilbbl/d|m3/d|abbr=on}} in 1995 down to approximately {{convert|385000|oilbbl/d|m3/d|abbr=on}} in 2010. Meanwhile, consumption is rising, which means that Syria could become a net oil importer within a decade.<ref name=PBReview/><ref name=USState/>{{update inline|?=yes|date=December 2015}} To counteract this problem, Syria intensified oil exploration efforts.
Syria's upstream oil production and development has traditionally been the mandate of the [[Syrian Petroleum Company]] (SPC), owned by the Syrian Ministry of Petroleum and Mineral Resources. SPC has undertaken efforts to reverse the trend toward declining oil production and exports by increasing oil exploration and production in partnership with foreign oil companies. The SPC directly controls about half of the country's oil production and takes a 50% stake in development work with foreign partners.<ref name=EIA/>
[[Foreign direct investment|Foreign investment]] is vital for improving production levels; however, following the outbreak of the Syrian Civil War, many countries important to Syria's oil exports have imposed sanctions, which legally prevents Western companies from working in the country.
Al-Furat Petroleum Company is a joint venture established in 1985. It is currently 50% owned by SPC and the other 50% is foreign owned: [[Royal Dutch Shell|Anglo-Dutch Shell]] with 32%, and the remainder held by Himalaya Energy Syria, a consortium of [[China National Petroleum Company]] and [[India]]'s [[Oil and Natural Gas Corporation]].<ref name=EIA/> The company produced an average {{convert|100000|oilbbl/d|m3/d|abbr=on}}. As of December 2011 Shell has suspended operations in Syria due to EU sanctions.<ref name=ft021211/>
Deir Ez Zor Petroleum Company is a consortium owned by SPC and [[France]]'s [[Total S.A.|Total]]. Total formed its Syrian operation in 1988 and in 2008 renewed its partnership sharing agreement with Syria. Prior to the Syrian Civil War, the company produced an average {{convert|27000|oilbbl/d|m3/d|abbr=on}} from its fields around [[Deir ez-Zour]].<ref name=OBG2010p103>{{cite book|title=Syria, 2010.|year=2010|publisher=Oxford Business Group|location=London|isbn=978-1-907065-16-3|page=103|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G851P_tsNtkC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Report:+Syria+2010+By+Oxford+Business+Group#v=snippet&q=sarkozy%20totla&f=false}}</ref>
A more recent entrant is the [[United Kingdom]]'s Gulfsands Petroleum. At the beginning of 2011, its oil fields produced {{convert|20700|oilbbl/d|m3/d|abbr=on}}.<ref name=Gulfsands>{{cite book |title=Gulfsands Petroleum Annual Report 2010 |page=18 |url=http://www.gulfsands.com/i/pdf/2010ARA.pdf |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813003438/http://www.gulfsands.com/i/pdf/2010ARA.pdf |archivedate=13 August 2011 |df= }}</ref> As of February 2012, Gulfsands has suspended its Syrian operations due to EU sanctions.<ref name=gulfsands/> Gulfsands dealings in Syria were also hit by EU sanctions due to Syrian tycoon [[Rami Makhlouf]], a cousin of the [[Syrian president]], holding 5.7% of the company,<ref name=Reuters>{{cite news|title=Gulfsands faces risk of extra EU sanctions on Syria|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/08/19/idUSL5E7JJ1YP20110819|accessdate=21 August 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=19 August 2011|first=Sarah|last=Young}}</ref> with this stake being suspended in August 2011 due to specific sanctions relating to Makhlouf.<ref>{{cite news|title=Syria: Gulfsands Petroleum suspends shares belonging to president Bashar al-Assad's cousin|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/energy/oilandgas/8720890/Syria-Gulfsands-Petroleum-suspends-shares-belonging-to-president-Bashar-al-Assads-cousin.html|accessdate=28 August 2012|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=24 August 2011|first=Rowena|last=Mason}}</ref> Other international players include or included: Canada's [[Suncor]], Poland's [[Kulczyk Investments|Kulczyk]], US-Egyptian firm IPR, Croatia's [[INA (company)|INA]], Russia's [[Stroytransgas]] and [[Soyuzneftegaz]], and Triton Singapore.<ref name=OBG95/><ref name=lemonde1> {{cite news |url= http://www.lemonde.fr/proche-orient/article/2013/12/25/la-russie-se-lance-dans-l-exploration-petroliere-en-syrie_4339807_3218.html |title= Russia launches into oil exploration in Syria (in French) |publisher= Le Monde |date=2013-12-25 |accessdate=2013-12-27}} </ref>
Another option to handle the increase in domestic oil consumption besides increasing oil production is to switch [[power station]]s from oil-fired to [[natural gas]]-fired. Proven natural gas reserves, approximately three-quarters of which are owned by the Syrian Petroleum Company, were estimated at 2.6 trillion cubic meters (9.1 trillion cubic feet) in 2010.<ref name=PBReview22>{{cite web|title=BP Statistical Review of World Energy June 2011|url=http://www.bp.com/assets/bp_internet/globalbp/globalbp_uk_english/reports_and_publications/statistical_energy_review_2011/STAGING/local_assets/pdf/statistical_review_of_world_energy_full_report_2011.pdf|publisher=British Petroleum. pp. 22|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref> A major challenge for the natural gas industry is logistics: reserves are located mainly in northeastern Syria, whereas the population is concentrated in the west and south.<ref>Syria country profile, pp. 10-11.</ref>

{{for|the British physician|Robert Daniel Lawrence}} {{Infobox writer |name = R. D. Lawrence |image = RD Lawrence.jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Ronald Douglas Lawrence |birth_date = {{Birth date|1921|09|12}} |birth_place = [[Bay of Biscay]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|2003|11|27|1921|09|12}} |death_place = [[Haliburton County]], Ontario, Canada |nationality = Canadian |occupation = Naturalist and writer |genre = Nature fiction and non-fiction |notableworks = ''Cry Wild'' (1970) }}
'''Ronald Douglas Lawrence''' (September 12, 1921 – November 27, 2003) was a [[Canadian]] naturalist and wildlife author. He was an expert on the [[wildlife of Canada]], on which he wrote more than thirty books, which have been published in 14 languages.<ref name="macleans">{{Cite magazine |last=Jenish |first=D. |date=August 19, 1996 |title=The call of the wild |magazine=Maclean's |volume=109 |issue=34 |pages=54–55}}</ref>
==Biography== ===Early life: Spain, Britain, and war=== Lawrence was born in 1921 on a British passenger ship in the [[Bay of Biscay]] off the coast of [[Spain]]. His mother was Spanish and his father, a journalist, was British. He was one of five children. As a child in northern Spain, Lawrence developed an early interest in nature. In his autobiography, he described his young self as a "happy loner engrossed in the natural world ... I cannot recall a single day when I was bored".<ref name="eh">{{Cite book |title=Earth Heroes: Champions of Wild Animals |last=Malnor |first=Carol |last2=Hovemann |first2=Anisa Claire |last3=Malnor |first3=Bruce |publisher=Dawn Publications |year=2010 |isbn=9781584691235 |pages=71–85 |chapter=Ronald 'RD' Lawrence}}</ref>
At 14 years, Lawrence lied about his age so that he could join the [[Republican faction (Spanish Civil War)|Republicans]] in the [[Spanish Civil War]], and killed a man on his first night to save himself.<ref name="eh"/> He served for two years, but finding himself outnumbered in the [[Pyrenees]], fled to France in 1938. Shortly after he traveled to Britain to rejoin his family, and during the summer of 1939 he worked on the ''[[RMS Queen Mary|Queen Mary]]''. With the arrival of World War II, he enlisted with the British and spent another five years at war, beginning in September 1939. He was a tank gunner in [[Battle of Dunkirk|Dunkirk]] and [[North African Campaign|North Africa]], and participated in [[Normandy landings|D-Day]] at Normandy, where he was seriously injured in August 1944.<ref name="star">{{Cite news |title=Great naturalist emerges from obscurity |last=Butala |first=Sharon |date=July 23, 1994 |work=Toronto Star |page=H12}}</ref> His leg was full of shrapnel, but he insisted that his leg not be amputated; instead, doctors removed 37 of 39 pieces of shrapnel, and Lawrence was determined to exercise the limb until he no longer walked with a limp.<ref name="eh"/> His war experiences scarred him, and are recounted in his 1994 autobiography, which he wrote at the encouragement of his publisher.<ref name="macleans"/>
After the war, he studied biology at [[Cambridge University]] for four years, but did not complete his degree. He found the environment stifling, with snobbish students and a [[pedagogy]] that ignored the first-hand experience of nature.<ref name="macleans"/><ref name="globe">{{Cite news |title=Wolf man was leader of the pack |last=Perkins |first=Martha |date=January 10, 2004 |work=The Globe and Mail |page=F8}}</ref> Following Cambridge, he went back to Spain, where he worked as a journalist and novelist and married a British woman. They had a son in 1953 after returning to Britain.<ref name="macleans"/>
===In Canada=== Lawrence moved to Canada alone in June 1954, later reflecting that "it was as if I had come home after a long absence".<ref name="macleans"/> Living in Toronto, he became a reporter for the ''[[Toronto Star]]''. Within six months he drove west to [[Rainy River, Ontario]] and purchased 100 acres of land for a homestead. His wife and son joined him in July 1955. For three years he made a living cutting timber from [[Crown land]] and selling it to mills. He and his wife had a second child, but his wife did not like their lifestyle in Canada, so she took the children to England and filed for divorce. Lawrence was left in the company of his four dogs, one part wolf, which he developed into a [[sled dog]] team. During this period Lawrence also sold fur pelts, but he came to view trapping as cruel, and stopped.<ref name="eh"/>
In 1957 Lawrence left the area and headed west, embarking on months-long wilderness excursions, which he supported by working for newspapers and living frugally. In southeastern [[British Columbia]] he tracked a [[cougar]] for nine months, and in Ontario he observed a [[beaver]] colony for six months.<ref name="macleans"/> Lawrence was extremely dedicated to wildlife observation, and believed that his close but unobtrusive study provided new insight into animal behavior. He said, for example, that he witnessed starving rabbits commit suicide by running their heads into trees, and saw [[herbivore]]s, like beavers, consume flesh.<ref name="macleans"/> During this period he met Joan, his second wife, in Winnipeg, with whom he raised orphaned animals. By this time Lawrence had rescued moose calves, bear cubs, and wolves.<ref name="eh"/> Joan died in 1969. His decades of wilderness adventure and study were the material of his nature writing.<ref name="eh"/><ref name="macleans"/>
Lawrence returned to Ontario and married Sharon, his third wife. They settled on a 100-acre property—his last home, called "Wolf Hollow"—in the [[Haliburton Highlands]]. He and Sharon rehabilitated wildlife, and Lawrence now lectured and supervised graduate students. According to his wife, "Ron mentored hundreds of young people ... so they in turn could continue to educate and influence younger generations".<ref name="eh"/>
The naturalist acknowledged [[Henry David Thoreau]] as a great influence in his life: "At fourteen I read ''[[Walden]]'' and was deeply impressed by one of Thoreau's sentences: 'In wildness is the preservation of the world.'"<ref name="eh"/> He was concerned and angry about humankind's treatment of nature, but generally kept his opinions out of his writing; he opposed [[clear-cut logging]] and the organized [[bear hunting|hunts of bears]] and wolves organized to control deer populations. He loved wolves and considered them the "ultimate stabilizers" in their ecosystems.<ref name="eh"/> In his memoir (''The Green Trees Beyond'', 1994), he wrote of his preference for nature over civilization, and explained how (per one reviewer) "he was taught to love for the first time by a wolf".<ref name="star"/> He reared a number of abandoned wolves: in his memoir, he wrote, "We cannot make up our minds whether we are a family of four people or a pack of four wolves ... The wolves, of course, have no doubt about the matter. They see us as a pack, Sharon fulfilling the role of much loved materfamilias, myself as the pack leader."<ref name="globe"/>
Lawrence finished his last book in 1997, and had four in progress at the time of his death. ''Cry Wild'' (1970), a book about wolves, is Lawrence's most popular; a 1991 reprint in the United States sold 1.5 million copies in three months.<ref name="macleans"/> Lawrence kept a low profile, which may explain his relative lack of fame in Canada, but his writing brought him much attention: he and Sharon received six thousand visitors to their Haliburton homestead over 12 years.<ref name="macleans"/> Lawrence died of [[Alzheimer's disease]] on November 27, 2003, in [[Haliburton County, Ontario]].<ref name="globe"/>
